SEEKING:

THE JETS:

[TONY] 18+ to play teen, Tenor (Bb2 – Bb4), White. The restless leader of the Jets, now looking for a new life. Sentimental enough to fall in love with Maria, but still believably angry enough to kill Bernardo. Passionate, playful, poetic, impulsive.

[RIFF] 18+ to play teen, Bari-tenor (Bb2 – G4), White. Tony’s best friend and fellow member of the Jets. Looking for security and family in the gang, plays in harmony with Tony. Struggling with the fact that things are changing. Athletic, sexy, a bit of a bully. Must be a strong dancer.

[ACTION] 18+ to play teen, Tenor (G2 – D5), White. Member of the Jets. Young and hot-headed, quick to anger and always ready for a fight. Unpredictable loose cannon who tries to mask his sensitive side with violence. Must be a strong dancer.

[ANYBODYS] 18+ to play teen, Alto, White. A spunky tomboy who is desperate to become a member of the Jets. The other Jets mock her for her ambitions but generally appreciate her company. Full of energy and heart. Must be a strong dancer.

[BABY JOHN] 18+ to play teen, Tenor, White. The youngest and most sensitive member of the Jets. Must be a strong dancer.

[A-RAB] 18+ to play teen, Baritone, White. Baby John’s best friend. Loyal with a mischievous streak and a sharp sense of humor. Must be a strong dancer.

[DIESEL] 18+ to play teen. Baritone, White. Riff’s second-in-command. Physically imposing. Becomes the leader of the Jets after Riff’s death. Must be a strong dancer

[BIG DEAL] 18+ to play teen, Baritone, White. A loudmouth who’s always ready to jump into trouble, often getting hurt but never backing down. Must be a strong dancer.

[SNOWBOY] 18+ to play teen, Tenor or Baritone, White. A wisecracking, rebellious member of the Jets. Must be a strong dancer.

[GEE-TAR] 18+ to play teen, Tenor or Baritone, White. A loyal friend and member of the Jets. Must be a strong dancer


THE SHARKS:

[MARIA] 18+ to play teen, Lyric soprano (Bb3 – C6.), Latina. Young naïve newcomer to America. Falls in love with Tony, willing to see the person beyond the gang leader. Romantic and sensitive, but also willful. Determined and direct, with a compelling authentic presence.

[ANITA] 20s, Mezzo belt (F3 – D5), Latina. Maria’s best friend and Bernardo’s girlfriend. Fighting for her place in the world and wants to enjoy life. Outspoken, street-smart, magnetic and confident. Devoted and protective, understands limits. Must be excellent dancer and singer.

[BERNARDO] 20s, Baritone (Bb2 – Eb4), Latino. Maria’s brother and Anita’s boyfriend. Leader of the Sharks. Fiercely proud, quick-tempered, protective of his family. Charismatic and cool but burning inside. Must be a strong dancer.

[CHINO] 18+ to play teen, Latino. Angry and, at times, naive Shark who turns murderous and vengeful. Suitor to Maria and friend of Bernardo's. Must be a strong dancer.


THE ADULTS:

[DOC] 50s – 60s. The owner of the candy store where the Jets hang out. He tries to guide the Jets youthful angst and provides a safe haven for Tony. Old fashioned and wise in his ways. Non-singing role.

[SCHRANK] 40s – 50s. A local police detective frustrated by the ongoing violence between the Jets and Sharks. Blunt, brash, and unapologetic. Non-singing role.

[KRUPKE] 40s – 50s. The local beat cop. He has no patience for the gang conflict and tries to keep tensions from erupting between them. Regularly mocked by the local gangs. Non-singing role.

[GLAD HAND] 40s – 50s. Nerdy, overly cheerful, and ill-equipped social director at the school dance. Non-singing role.

COST $1214 weekly minimum (Tier 4)

title: AUTOMATION TECHNICIAN - EXPRESSION OF INTEREST
description:
Hale Centre Theatre
Sandy, UT
US
JOB DETAILS
DESCRIPTION

SUMMARY
Hale Centre Theatre is building a pool of experienced automation professionals interested in operating and maintaining our state-of-the-art Automation systems for our award-winning productions.

Our Automation team supports multiple venues and collaborates closely with creative and technical departments to deliver safe, innovative, and technically seamless live performances. Team members work with advanced stage machinery and show control technology in a fast-paced, production-driven environment that values precision, training, and continuous improvement.

This posting is intended to identify and connect with qualified candidates for future openings within our Automation Department.

RESPONSIBILITIES
As a full-time Automation Technician, you will be an integral part of the Automation team, responsible for operating and maintaining automated show elements and control systems within the theaters at the Mountain America Performing Arts Center for Hale Centre Theatre. Your duties will include operating automation consoles during performances and performing automation maintenance tasks such as inspecting scenery and rigging, assisting with show installations, supporting special projects, and conducting preventative maintenance.

ESSENTIAL DUTIES AND RESPONSIBILITIES

Operate the automation control console in a safe and consistent manner for performances, performer/technician training, and maintenance operations.
Complete all required documentation such as pre-show checklists as directed.
Report issues occurred during performances in applicable logs and/or designated reporting methods.
Assist with maintenance and routine safety inspections on automation equipment and systems.
Assist with rigging tasks and projects during show strikes and installations.
Develop a thorough knowledge of all Automation Department equipment.
Participate in department trainings and development processes.
Troubleshoot electrical, software, and mechanical problems should they arise.
Work with other technical departments to maintain safety policies and procedures for maintenance, training, performer rescues, and performances.
Perform other duties assigned by HCT leadership.
EDUCATION, EXPERIENCE AND SKILLS REQUIRED
2+ years of operational experience with theatrical automation systems. (TAIT Navigator is a bonus).
2+ years of experience working and/or maintaining large-scale theatrical productions.
1+ years of experience working with theatrical rigging elements.
Bachelor's Degree or equivalent experience in automation, theatre or a related field.
Understanding of the various elements of the theatre process – production, technical and performance.
Excellent written and verbal communication skills. Knowledge and usage of correct English grammar, spelling, and punctuation.
Strong organizational and administrative skills – detail oriented.
Ability to problem-solve and facilitate solutions to issues.
Ability to learn quickly and adapt rapidly when required.
Ability to work productively under time pressures and meet deadlines.
Ability to work independently and exercise excellent decision-making skills.
High level of computer proficiency with knowledge of word processing, spreadsheets.
Works well in a stressful environment with many personality types.
Ability to work long hours and to manage an irregular schedule including weekends and holidays.
Proven ability to work independently and collaboratively in a fast paced, rapidly changing environment.
Ability to work in an active team environment.
Willingness to learn and grow.
Ability to lift 50lbs+.
Ability to work at heights of 75ft+.
PREFERRED EXPERIENCE AND SKILLS
TAIT Navigator Automation Software operating and/or programming experience.
Experience operating and/or programming performer flying systems.
Basic knowledge of Siemens or Beckhoff PLC, IO, & control systems pertaining to automated stage machinery.

Hourly compensation commensurate with experience. Individual compensation packages are based on various factors unique to each candidate, including skill set, experience, and qualifications

SALARY

$33.00 – $36.50 per hour
HOW TO APPLY
APPLY ONLINE

https://careers.hct.org/apply/oSsoTWgeP1/Automation-Technician-Expression-Of-Interest

title: THE HOMOSEXUALS, BY PHILIP DAWKINS (OUT/PLAY)
description:
OUTPLAY
New York, NY
US
JOB DETAILS
DESCRIPTION
THE HOMOSEXUALS, by Philip Dawkins.
Directed by Christopher Basile. Produced by OUT/PLAY.

To be performed under the Equity Showcase Code for this production. Both AEA and Non-Equity performers are encouraged to apply.

Actors will receive a $100 total stipend for rehearsals and performances.

IMPORTANT DATES:

Callbacks: Sunday, February 15

Table Read and Rehearsals Begin: Sunday, February 22

Performances:
Friday, April 3, 2026 at 7PM;
Saturday, April 4 at 7PM;
Sunday, April 5 at 3PM;
Sunday, April 5 at 7PM (possible addition);
Friday, April 10, 2026 at 7PM;
Saturday, April 11 at 7PM;
Sunday, April 12 at 3PM;
Sunday, April 12 at 7PM (possible addition)

CHARACTER BREAKDOWN:

The play begins in 2010 and runs backward until the final scene which takes place in 2000. So, the first scene of the play is the last chronologically (eg: in the first scene of the play, Evan is 29, and in the last scene, he is 20).

Peter: (Man; mid 40s, to play age 48 and 38) Artistic director of a prominent American regional theatre. Overtly and unapologetically flamboyant. If you cut him, he would bleed glitter. At the end of the play, Peter is in a long-term relationship with Mark. At the start of the play, he is dating Evan.

British Mark: (Man; mid/late 30s, to play age 38 and 31) A lawyer. Best friends with Collin, whom he met while at University in England (where—it hopefully goes without saying—he is from). British Mark is dependable without being a martyr, attractive without much trying, and kind without being nice. Incredibly charming and often impulsive. Actor will be in their underwear and in sexual situations with another actor.

Tam: (Woman, early/mid 30s, to play age 32 and 28) When we first see her, Tam is a 5th grade teacher at an inner-city “at risk” school. At the end of the play, she is an Art History professor at the same university where Mark teaches. She’s an organizer, a do-er, a shaker, and she can drink you under the table.

Mark: (Man, early 40s/late 30s, to play age 40 and 38) The chairperson of a small university art department. Caustic, blunt, scathing, icy, but all in an extremely sexy way. Mark wears his militant sexuality on his sleeve, and he prides himself on being a radical sex-positive activist. We don’t know this for a fact, but he’s probably into leather. At the end of the play, Mark is in a long term relationship with Peter. Actor will be seen shirtless in a sheet, with some possible nudity.

Collin: (Man, early 30s, to play age 31) A lawyer. Best friends with British Mark. Collin has recently lost 125 pounds and is celebrating his new-found slender self. He is the glue connecting each member of his little urban tribe.

Evan Wilder: (Man, to play age 30 through 20) *ALREADY CAST*
Michael: (Man, early/mid 30s, to play age 32 and 26) *ALREADY CAST*

PLEASE NOTE:

OUT/PLAY is committed to diversity across race, ethnicity, color, religion, sex, sexual orientation, gender identity, national origin, veteran or disability status.
Directors will be coordinating rehearsals according to actor availability, though availability on weekends is a plus.
Actors must be off-book for all shows.
Director and actors are responsible for promoting the show on social media and through mailing lists. As a non-profit organization, OUT/PLAY needs everyone's participation for success.
All company members will receive a $5 discount code for tickets.

OUT/PLAY's 2025-2026 SEASON

OCTOBER 2025: Caffe Cino One-Acts
DECEMBER 2025: Uncommon Women, by Wendy Wasserstein
FEBRUARY 2026: Love In a Plague: Scenes from AIDS Plays
APRIL 2026: The Homosexuals, by Philip Dawkins
JUNE 2026: Summer Shorts New Play Festival

OUT/PLAY'S MISSION STATEMENT: Empower Queer Theatre Artists to bring new life to Queer plays for contemporary audiences. This season is dedicated to Queers Thru The Years, highlighting playwrights and stories throughout Queer History from 1950s to today.

title: SEEKING PERFORMERS FOR VARIOUS IMMERSIVE ROLES
description:
New York Renaissance Faire
Tuxedo, NY
US
JOB DETAILS
DESCRIPTION

To audition for the New York Renaissance Faire you will need to submit a recording to the New York Renaissance Faire 2026 Audition Form. Submissions will be closed on Monday March 16th, 2026 at 12:00 PM. Callback Invitations will be sent by Wednesday March 25th. Callbacks are scheduled for Saturday March 28th and Sunday March 29th. You will not be considered for the fight based roles if you are not invited or are unable to attend the fight call on Saturday March 28th in New York City in person.




PLEASE HAVE PREPARED FOR YOUR AUDITION SUBMISSION
- Resume
- Headshot
- Two contrasting monologues (approximately 45 seconds each)
-16 bars of your favorite song to sing acapella.
- * If you play an instrument at performance level please prepare a 30-second demonstration.*




FIGHT BASED ROLE AUDITIONS MUST ADDITIONALLY PREPARE:
- Fight Audition Tape consisting the of required material presented in the Stage Combat Audition Choreography 2026




FAE CAST AUDITIONS MUST ADDITIONALLY PREPARE:
- 60 second recording of movement. Pick an animal (DO NOT say which one) and using your full body and multiple levels, tell us a physical story wherein you discover something new in your space. Combine animal like gestures with mystical elements of movement to showcase your fae’s personality and perspective.


To submit your audition, visit our website at renfair.com/ny/join-us/. Any questions can be sent to the nyrfentertainment@gmail.com.



NYRF CAST & ROLES INFORMATION




Daily Rate Range for Performance Days: $64 - $120 (rehearsals are unpaid)




*All roles receive a Day Rate for the 8 weekends of performances between August 15th through October 4th (17 days including Labor Day Monday). Rehearsals are unpaid and opportunity for tent camping is provided. Meals are not provided. Rehearsals are only Saturdays and Sundays from June 13th to August 9th.*




We are casting various roles for several casts including:




Chess Masters: The caretakers of the infamous Chess Board who assist in several shows and host interactive experiences and games for all guests visiting the shire. Roles focus on guest immersion and children centric entertainment while assisting with the overall production.




Fae (Movement Cast): These fantastikal, magical, and somewhat mischievous creatures combine elements of mime, ASL, and movement to bring whimsy, wonder, and a bit of mayhem to the shire for adults and children alike. Roles are focused on movement, and child-friendly entertainment and storytelling.




*Additional audition material required, see above*




Golden Boarstags: The Golden Boarstags, a renown mercenary company, is a cast based around hosting and monitoring the Pub Crawl, a stand alone experience at the New York Renaissance Faire. Additionally, the Golden Boarstags creates and performs a comedic variety show at the end of the day. Throughout the day there is much opportunity to flex your acting chops as we employ ample improv comedy, musical talent and general (but controlled) mischief. This cast does require the ability to walk for long periods, a willingness to engage with guests who are consuming alcohol, and the enthusiasm to create and workshop entertainment with fellow castmates.




*Servsafe certification will be required and training provided for employment.*




Guild of St. George (Includes Fight Roles): Within the greater Performance Company, The Guild of Saint George ensemble provides a theatrical portrayal of the working court of Queen Elizabeth I on royal progress. GoSG achieves the primary goal of inclusion and elevation by welcoming guests into a little slice of Elizabethan courtly life, greeting patrons as fellow esteemed nobility, with pageantry and personability. The Guild of St. George focuses on historical fantasy, ensemble work, stylized movement for the purpose of storytelling, or even sitting one-on-one with guests in a moment of connection across time.




*Including one heightened language monologue would be encouraged for those interested in auditioning for the Guide of St. George cast.*




The Queen’s Blades (Guild of St. George): The Queen’s Blades is a sparring tournament that takes place in the Guild of Saint George for Her Majesty’s entertainment. Six sword fighters, armed with a variety of weapons, will duel in pairs to the disarm or yield, showcasing their skills and competing for the Queen’s favor. All the while, the rest of the Court and the audience propose wagers and cheer for their champions! This show is for those interested in historical martial arts, witty banter and (mostly) friendly competition, and exploring stage combat in a smaller, more intimate setting within the larger scheme of our performance day.




*A Stage Combat Video Submission and attendance at the Fight Call on Saturday March 28th is required to participate. Armed Stage Combat Training is preferred*




The Heralds: The Heralds are a group of nautically-themed performers who bring joy and music to our guests while providing immersive crowd management. There are opportunities to perform at several events during the day, including "Hark the Heralds!" (a singing stage show full of sea shanties), a Pirate Maypole, and hosts various themed balls throughout the season. The Heralds are looking for talented improv performers, actor-singer-musicians, and folks interested in in-character patron management and communication. An adequate dancing ability and a passion for teaching simple steps is encouraged!




Musica Diegetica: Calling all musicians to Musica Diagetica, the heartbeat of the faire. This cast provides the musical soundtrack for the biggest events, including the jousts, chess matches, court dances and maypoles. There are additional opportunities to shine in independent band sets and intimate character interactions. We are looking for intermediate to advanced players with an ability to read music or learn by ear quickly and accurately. All instruments are welcome but we are particularly looking for trumpet, trombone, percussion, violin, viola, and various woodwinds (Electronic instruments need not apply).




Revelers: These rowdy rambunctious rockstars sing songs, dance maypoles, and interact with the audience, creating the thrumming life of shire. Roles focus on improvisation and immersive theater directly with audience members.




Robin Hood Scenario (Fight Cast): The Robin Hood Scenario cast tells the tale of Robin Hood coming into his own as a leader of a Merry Band of outlaws, who come to blows against the power hungry Sheriff and guards. *SAFD training recommended.




Additional opportunities available post casting:




Shakespeare in the Shire:

Shakespeare in the Shire (SitS) is a daily performance that features a rotating lineup of monologues, scenes, songs, and games all taken from or inspired by the works of William Shakespeare. It is an extracurricular of sorts, requiring one extra hour of time at the end of Saturday rehearsal days, with opportunities for director and peer feedback. On the whole, we encourage exploration, play, and creativity to bring the works of the Bard to life!




Within the ensemble, there will be a dedicated small group of improvisers - The Rude Mechanicals - however, there will also be opportunity for large group games, so everyone has a chance to join the merriment. If you love Shakespeare or any part of his works, we’d love to have you!




Requirements: one of your submitted monologues must be Shakespeare




Pastoral Dance Show:

The Pastoral Show is a renaissance period inspired dance show that takes place on the chess board once per performance day! Historically, a pastoral dance is a choreographed performance that celebrates the beauty and wonder of nature and rural living. This cross cast show marries pastoral’s historical thesis while providing a spectacular moment of entertainment for the esteemed guests who come through our gates.

If you are interested in auditioning for the Pastoral Show, please note interest in dancing and your dance level on the audition form when submitting. You can also ask to speak with the Dance Director at auditions. Please note that the dance call to audition for Pastoral will take place on the first “all company” rehearsal day post casting finalizations and contract acceptance.
DURATION

Jun 13, 2026 - Oct 4, 2026

SALARY

$64.00 – $120.00 per day
HOW TO APPLY
APPLY ONLINE

https://renfair.com/ny/join-us/

JOB DETAILS
DESCRIPTION

JOB DATES: 6/18/26–8/15/26

Using the framework of themed weeks, NLBP Summer Camps are a fun and educational opportunity for young people ages 6-11. Camps are designed to be an introduction to various theatrical talents including acting, musical theater, technical theater, playwriting, improvisation, dance, puppetry, and more. A single camp takes place Monday-Friday from 9am–4pm, with a showcase for friends and family at the end of the week. This year, there will be 8 weeks of summer camps. Teaching Artists for NLBP Summer Camps should have at least 1 year of experience in theater education with a passion for working with young artists.

RESPONSIBILITIES AND DUTIES:

-Plan and execute an engaging and educational week-long curriculum according to the camp title and theme (with guidance and resources provided by the Camps Director)

-Lead and participate in camp activities which include, but are not limited to, singing, dancing, warm-ups and introducing techniques through relevant acting and musical theatre exercises

-Communicate frequently with the Camps Director before camp start date to prepare, approve, and finalize curriculum

-Communicate with co-teacher to collaborate and distribute duties

-Communicate with Camp Leadership to ensure that all materials needed for camp will be provided

-Teach/facilitate your camp according to your prepared and approved curriculum, working toward a 15-minute showcase at the end of the week

-Provide a fun environment for all campers while ensuring the safety and welfare of participants at all times

-Identify and respond to campers’ classroom conduct

-Communicate with parents about participant’s experiences and report concerns to Camp Leadership

-Classroom set-up and clean-up

-Manage attendance and emergency contact information for campers

-Assist with walking the campers from the camp location to the Barn or Barn-related events nearby

-Provide basic first aid if needed

REQUIREMENTS / SKILLS:

-1 year of experience in education and/or youth theater or equivalent

-CPR/First Aid certification a plus

-Must pass a state of New Hampshire background check

-Comfort with creating lessons plans and documenting curriculum

-Ability to motivate, facilitate and direct youth ages 6-11 and create a classroom culture of respect and participation

-Desire to learn and grow in teaching practice

-Excellent classroom management skills

-Ability to work in a rigorous, fast-paced environment

-Work in a team environment with ability to work independently

-Excellent organizational and time management skills

-Strong interpersonal and communication skills

-A sense of humor and fun

COMPENSATION:

-Travel stipend

title: ASSISTANT STAGE MANAGER - THE STARTUP WORKSHOP PRODUCTION
description:
The Startup Musical
New York, NY
US
JOB DETAILS
DESCRIPTION
The Startup is a brand new musical premiering its workshop production at The Flea Theater in NYC in April 2026. We are looking for a dedicated, kind and efficient Assistant Stage Manager to join our amazing team for this upcoming production!

Show Synopsis:
The Startup is a sharp, satirical new musical about the price we pay for digital fame. Set in the cutthroat world of Big Tech, it follows Chip Cooper and his idealistic team as they try to build a more ethical social media platform, just as their company teeters on the edge of collapse.

With biting humor and bold heart, The Startup dives into our tangled relationship with technology, tackling everything from social media use and data privacy to influencer culture and the rise of AI. It’s a timely story about ambition, integrity, and what we're willing to sacrifice in the pursuit of success.

ASM Responsibilities:


• Support the Stage Manager in coordinating and managing all rehearsals, technical rehearsals, and performances for the workshop production of The Startup.

• Assist with daily rehearsal operations, including setup, prop tracking, scene transitions, and maintaining a clean and organized rehearsal space.

• Prepare and update run sheets, prop lists, and cue documentation under the guidance of the Stage Manager and Production Manager.

• Oversee backstage operations during technical rehearsals and performances, including performer entrances, quick changes, and prop handoffs.

• Assist in calling cues or running backstage tracks as assigned, ensuring accuracy and consistency throughout the production run.

• Communicate effectively with the Stage Manager, technical team, and cast, helping to coordinate transitions and resolve issues quickly and calmly.

• Attend all production meetings, technical rehearsals, and performances, remaining flexible to evolving production needs throughout the workshop process.

• Adhere to the developmental nature of the workshop and remain open to adjustments during rehearsals and previews.

• Communicate respectfully and professionally with all members of the company and adhere to Equity Showcase Code standards.

• Assist in maintaining a safe, inclusive, and collaborative working environment, ensuring that backstage operations meet the highest standards of professionalism and safety.

Production Schedule:
Rehearsals: Rehearsals will begin with our first read-through/rehearsal on Saturday Feb 28, and will run until we reach our TECH rehearsals beginning Saturday March 28. Rehearals will be Monday-Thursday evenings and Saturdays during the day, with Sundays and Fridays off until TECH.

TECH: ALL DAY Sat March 28 and Sun March 29

Performances:
Dress rehearsal: Tues March 31
Previews: April 1-4
Opening Night: April 8
Run of show: April 8-19
*two shows on Saturdays, OFF Mondays and Tuesdays during the performance run. There will only be one matinee performance for the Saturday 4/4 preview.

The assistant stage manager is expected to be available for tech, previews, and all performances. We can be flexible with any other conflicts you might have during the rehearsal period.

Because this is a workshop production, we are working with a very limited budget. We can provide a stipend of $200 for your involvement with this project.

This is a wonderful opportunity for an emerging stage manager to get valuable experience working on a new work in development. Please email thestartupmusical@gmail.com with your resume if you are interested. Please put in the subject line: "Assistant Stage Manager Submission- THE STARTUP" We are looking to hire this role ASAP, so the sooner you submit the better.

We look forward to hearing from you!

title: SUMMER ACCOMPANIST
description:
Aloha Foundation
Fairlee, VT
US

CONTACT NAME

Bryan Partridge
JOB DETAILS
DESCRIPTION

Job Description: Pianist Accompanist and Counselor at the Aloha Camps

 

Are you a talented theater Pianist Accompanist with a passion for working with children? Do you have a knack for creating a fun and inclusive musical atmosphere? If so, we have the perfect opportunity for you! Join Camp Lanakila as a Piano Accompanist and Counselor, where you can inspire young campers through the power of music.

Responsibilities:

As Music Director

Serve as Music Director for the first half musical. This includes playing piano for the performances. 

Make sure the piano is kept in good condition. This means making sure the cover is always on, and that the the lid is put down over the keys every night.  Since it is practically outdoors the moisture builds up on the keys and it is very unpleasant to play the next morning. Everyone at camp is welcome to use the piano, and most won’t remember to cover the keys when they are done. 

As Camp Pianist:

Provide lively and engaging piano accompaniment for all camp singing at bi-weekly assembly, campfire sing-alongs, talent show performances, and other camp events. Bring the magic of music to life!

Collaborate with campers and other staff members to create musical arrangements and performances. Encourage campers to explore their musical talents and express themselves through music.

Assist and support campers in rehearsing and practicing their individual musical performances. Foster their confidence and growth as musicians.

Occasionally lead group music sessions, teaching campers basic piano skills or introducing them to new instruments. Ignite their love for music!

As a Counselor:

Act as a positive role model and mentor for campers, fostering a supportive and inclusive camp community. Help create lasting memories for campers!

Engage and participate in camp activities and team-building exercises. Foster a sense of belonging and fun for all campers.

Supervise and ensure the safety of campers during all camp activities, including meal times, overnight stays, and off-site excursions. Their safety is our priority!

Qualifications:

Proficient piano skills and the ability to read sheet music, with a diverse repertoire. Show off your versatility in playing various genres!

Prior experience working with children, such as teaching music lessons or leading youth groups. Patience and a genuine interest in nurturing young minds are key.

Strong communication and interpersonal skills, with the ability to connect with campers of different ages and backgrounds. Build trust and rapport easily!

An energetic and enthusiastic attitude, with the ability to create a positive and inclusive camp environment. Infuse campers with your infectious energy!

Perks:

Making a meaningful impact on the lives of campers, fostering their love for music and helping them develop lifelong skills and confidence.

Enjoying the beauty of the outdoors as Aloha Hive Summer Camp is located amidst stunning natural surroundings. Refresh your creativity with nature!

Collaborating with a passionate and supportive staff team, sharing ideas and experiences to create an unforgettable summer for campers and staff alike.

Participating in all camp activities and enjoying the vibrant camp atmosphere. Embrace your inner child and have fun!

Competitive compensation package, including room and board during the camp season. Focus on what you do best while we take care of the logistics.

Ready to embark on a summer of music, fun, and personal growth? Join Camp Lanakila as an accompanist/Pianist and Counselor, and help create camp memories that will last a lifetime!

title: AD: TRAIN WITH LAMDA IN NYC - SPRING CLASSES IN DANCE AND ACCENTS
description:
LAMDA
New York, NY
US
JOB DETAILS
DESCRIPTION

Train this Spring with the London Academy of Music & Dramatic Art (LAMDA) in our New York City location.

STORYTELLING THROUGH DANCE with LAMDA's Head of Dance, Gregory Haney
March 5-6, 2026 from 6:30pm - 9:00pm
Course Level: Professional / Age Requirement: 18+



The class will comprise floor technique, followed by choreography, culminating in character into choreography. You'll come away with tools and techniques to bring a character to life through dance. This class is suitable for all actors, dancers and performers with baseline choreo pick-up ability. Gregory Haney is an accomplished actor, choreographer and movement director with extensive background on Broadway, the West End, and in film, TV and music videos. This course is geared for professional dancers, actors and performers. Whilst participants do not need to specialise in dance, this class does require baseline choreography retention. LAMDA NY Short Courses are presented in partnership with American Friends of LAMDA (AFLAMDA).




BRITISH ACCENTS with LAMDA NY Voice Instructor, Atticus Orsborn
April 25-26, 2026 from 10:00am - 5:30pm
Course Level: Professional / Age Requirement: 21+

This in-depth weekend course is an invaluable opportunity to spend some deep and dedicated time working on your British accent(s). Designed for professional working actors, you’ll be guided through the technical aspects of creating a British accent, before moving on to discovering how to sit in and embody the accent as your own. You’ll be encouraged to find truth, connection and ease over perfection and impersonation, and you’ll finish up the weekend with a reliable British accent(s) you can be confident in.


LAMDA is a truly global drama school, having been ranked 6th by the Hollywood Reporter in its list of the best drama schools in the world. Since its inception in 1861, LAMDA has offered exceptional vocational training to actors, stage managers, technicians, directors and designers, regardless of their background or economic circumstances. With many of our alumni being from the USA and going on to consistently work across Broadway, Off-Broadway, and film and television, New York City was a natural fit for the home of our first international studio.

Mar 5, 2026 - Apr 26, 2026

NON-UNION

title: COSTUMED TOUR GUIDE/ SUPPORT STAFF
description:
Alaska 360 LLC
Skagway, AK
US

CONTACT NAME

Angela McCain
JOB DETAILS
DESCRIPTION

***$16/hr regular wage, $1/regular wage hour worked end-of-season bonus when contract completed. Character Tour Guide / Support Staff are eligible for tips. Guides MUST be able to arrive in Skagway by April 23rd - Training begins April 25th, 2026; Contract End Date is Sept 30th, 2026. Subsidized housing is $300/month, double occupancy, deducted from the paycheck. Pets are not allowed in company housing.***

Position Brief

Alaska 360 is seeking energetic, engaging, and adventurous individuals to join our team of 1890s Costumed Tour Guides and Support Staff for the summer season in Skagway, Alaska. Alaska 360’s Costumed Tour Guides dress in period costumes and take on the personas of prospectors and other members of the 1898 Gold Rush community. As a Costumed Tour guide, you will bring the spirit of the 1890s to life! You’ll guide groups of 12-50 guests on an interactive gold rush experience filled with laughter, storytelling, and local history. This is a hands-on, high-energy role where creativity can shine.

General Responsibilities

Alaska 360 takes great care to train and maintain a professional and knowledgeable cast of characters to perform daily tasks and execute the company’s tour offerings for all guests who visit Alaska 360’s Dredge Town. When you are not leading tours, Costumed Tour Guides/Support Staff will assist fellow guides, support the Back of House (BOH) operations, perform tasks that help upkeep the operations of Alaska 360’s retail center and restaurant areas, and complete tasks to maintain the tour grounds. This position reports to multiple supervisors and managers throughout the day and is expected to carry out the company’s mission and represent the values of the company to the guests and to his/her colleagues. Costumed Tour Guides/Support Staff assume a persona from the Klondike Gold Rush era and work in period costumes.

Key Responsibilities and Accountabilities

Welcome and retrieve guests from the assigned tour from the assigned cruise ship

Works as a Dock Representative for their assigned tour under the supervision of Alaska 360's Operations Team with duties including interaction with guests, transportation companies and cruise ship employees

Acts as a Costumed Tour Guide for their assigned tour, which may include components such as the White Pass train, the Gold Rush Training Camp, the Sixty Mile Dredge, the Campfire, and Gold Panning

Provides support for Back of House (BOH) operations (gold panning, assaying of gold, and/or resetting of the BOH tour elements)

Works in the retail area (mainly assaying gold) as an essential component of the tours

Helps with maintenance and cleaning tasks throughout the day

May assist in opening and closing tasks in the Retail Center and/Restaurant areas on a rotating basis. Tasks may include, but are not limited to, maintaining restrooms and general areas, providing inventory support, assembling snack bags, and other tour-focused supplies, etc

Works daily with multiple supervisors, managers, and partners with other cast members

Ensures a clean, clutter-free work environment

Educational Background

High School Diploma or equivalent (GED)

Degree or training in drama, theatre and/or education helpful

Experience in sales, retail or hospitality a plus

A high degree of knowledge about gold and Alaska through coursework and study is also a plus!

Professional Experience

Experience in hospitality, education, theme parks or tourism- helpful

Experience in sales or retail- a plus

Experience in theatre, education, musical talent, juggling, storytelling, comedy, or other performing or public speaking- desired

Love of history and a desire to inspire others to appreciate it- a necessity

Required Skills & Abilities

Good interpersonal skills for daily interactions with individual guests and groups

Eager to learn and have a growth mindset

Strong presentation/acting skills. Comfortable speaking to groups between 12 and 50 guests

Versatility - fulfill multiple rotating positions and transition quickly between the site segments

Reliable, adaptable, and a great team player

Commitment to making the guests’ experience a top priority

Continued participation and interest in educational material relevant to Alaska, the Klondike Gold Rush, gold, and Skagway

Ability to work as part of a team, including up to 40 employees

Outgoing, friendly, and confident personality

Ability to lift 40lbs throughout the workday

Ability to stand and walk for an 8-hour workday

Ability to work a full season (late April through early October)

Why You’ll Love It

Become part of a company that values collaboration, development, and excellence and join a fun, creative, and supportive team

Work in a challenging but very rewarding job in a fast-paced, high-volume environment with plenty of opportunities for growth

Spend your summer in one of Alaska’s most breathtaking historic towns

Perform outdoors and meet travelers from around the world

Have access to low-cost quality company housing

Gain public speaking, performance, and customer service experience

Build memories—and friendships—that last a lifetime!

Join us this season for a rewarding experience in one of the most remarkable regions of the world.

DURATION

Apr 23, 2026 - Sep 30, 2026

SALARY

$17.00 – $17.00 per hour

title: STAGE AND COMPANY MANAGER
description:
BalletX
Philadelphia, PA
US
JOB DETAILS
DESCRIPTION

Stage and Company Manager




Reports to: Director of Production

Location: Philadelphia, PA (with travel as required)

Status: Full-time




BalletX, Philadelphia’s premier contemporary ballet, seeks a Stage and Company Manager to serve as the company’s resident stage manager and a key partner in both production and company operations. This full-time position plays a vital role in supporting rehearsals, performances, tours, and the day-to-day logistics of working with dancers and guest artists, ensuring that artistic work moves forward smoothly, efficiently, and with care.




The Stage and Company Manager works closely with artistic leadership, dancers, choreographers, guest artists, and the production team to support the creation and presentation of new and existing repertory. From stage managing rehearsals and performances to coordinating company travel and serving as a primary liaison for guest artists, this role bridges artistic, production, and administrative functions. The ideal candidate is highly organized, calm under pressure, people-centered, and excited to contribute to a collaborative environment that values both artistic excellence and strong operational systems.




To learn more about BalletX, our mission, and our programs, visit www.BalletX.org.




This position is full-time with a salary range of $60,000-$70,000 (commensurate with experience) and accompanying benefits including health insurance, 401k match, and paid time off. BalletX is an equal opportunity employer.




Key Responsibilities

Stage Management and Performance Support

- Serve as the primary stage manager for all BalletX performances, tours, and productions
- Prepare and maintain calling sheets, cue lists, rehearsal and performance reports, and related documentation
- Coordinate backstage operations, crew communication, and performance flow
- Ensure safe, efficient backstage environments during rehearsals and performances
- Assist with load-ins, spacing rehearsals, technical rehearsals, and strikes
- Document and report incidents, injuries, or safety concerns to the Director of Production in a timely manner




Company Management and Artist Logistics

- Coordinate travel arrangements for company dancers, staff, and guest artists, including flights, ground transportation, lodging, and itineraries
- Prepare, track, and maintain travel budgets in coordination with the Director of Production
- Serve as a primary liaison for guest artists, supporting onboarding, scheduling, travel, housing, and day-to-day logistics
- Distribute itineraries and provide clear communication to artists and staff while on tour or traveling for performances
- Track travel-related expenses and assist with reconciliation and reporting
- Support company members and guest artists with logistical needs while traveling or in residence




Rehearsal and Studio Coordination

- Support studio rehearsals by coordinating schedules, space use, and rehearsal logistics
- Oversee and maintain the general studio calendar, ensuring accurate scheduling of company rehearsals, artistic activities, and production-related studio use
- Coordinate studio scheduling needs with the Director of Production and other departments as required
- Track rehearsals, casting, understudy coverage, and artistic notes
- Serve as a primary point of communication between dancers, choreographers, and artistic leadership during rehearsal periods
- Support spacing rehearsals and transitions from studio to stage
- Assist with rehearsal documentation and artistic record-keeping




Artistic Coordination and Documentation

- Support artistic staff with scheduling, planning, and coordination needs
- Assist in maintaining accurate repertory records, production notes, cue archives, and artistic documentation
- Support the Director of Production in ensuring alignment between artistic intent and production execution




Communication and Collaboration

- Serve as a central communication hub during rehearsal, performance, and travel periods
- Maintain clear, professional communication with dancers, guest artists, crew, and staff
- Uphold a calm, respectful, and supportive rehearsal and performance environment
- Support onboarding and orientation of dancers, guest artists, and seasonal production staff into rehearsal, performance, and touring processes




Desired Attributes

- Highly organized, detail-oriented, and proactive, with the ability to anticipate needs and troubleshoot independently
- Calm, steady, and clear-headed in fast-paced or high-pressure environments
- Strong interpersonal skills with a people-centered approach to working with artists, staff, and collaborators
- Excellent communicator who can balance clarity, diplomacy, and warmth
- Adaptable and flexible, with a positive attitude toward change, touring, and evolving schedules
- Discreet and trustworthy when handling sensitive information and artist needs
- Collaborative mindset with a willingness to step in wherever needed to support the team and the work




Qualifications and Experience

- 3-5 years of professional stage management experience in dance or live performance
- Experience with company management, touring logistics, or artist travel coordination strongly preferred
- Strong understanding of rehearsal processes, production flow, and backstage operations
- Exceptional organizational, communication, and problem-solving skills
- Ability to remain composed and solutions-oriented under pressure
- Willingness to work evenings, weekends, and tour as required
- Valid driver’s license and comfort driving rental vehicles on tour




To Apply

To apply, please send your cover letter, resume, and three references to BalletX at jobs@balletx.org.

Applications will be reviewed on a rolling basis until the position is filled.

SALARY

$60,000.00 – $70,000.00 per year

A psychological journey into the subconscious of 8th grader, JACOB, and his outlandish epiphany.

JACOB: 13 (almost 14), JV quarterback and assistant coach, HAA’s Most Christlike




PEYTON: 13, wide receiver, a bit cynical, a bit logical. His brother is in a gang.

As JV assistant coach, quarterback, president of robotics club, alter boy (every Sunday), general member of drama club (for the art credit), and all around Good Samaritan, it was no surprise that Jacob was chosen for this year‘s graduation pageant. This is a mighty position to fill, and it’ll take some convincing. Mainly from his fellow JV teammates as speakers in the ceremony, Mason and childhood best friend Peyton. title: TECHNICAL THEATER PRODUCTION SUPERVISOR
description:
Success Academy Charter Schools
New York, NY
US
JOB DETAILS
DESCRIPTION

Thanks for your interest in Success Academy! Running a large, fast-growing, and high-performing network of public charter schools takes a village - families, children, teachers, staff and faculty, advocates, and supporters alike. We are growing fast in New York and expanding to Florida, and we would love to welcome you to our community! We work tirelessly every day to ensure children have access to a fun, rigorous, whole-child education regardless of zip code or economic status. When you join SA, you play a part in giving every student who walks through our doors a fair shot at reaching his or her potential.

The Bronx K-12 Technical Theatre Supervisor is a school-based role that additionally oversees and provides supplemental guidance for all K-12 Bronx Campus technical theatre objectives related to the auditorium. This role reports to Success Academy’s Theater Program Manager. This role will be salary-based and required to attend rehearsals that take place after school-based hours and occasionally other duties during the day affiliated with the assembly/maintenance of productions. This role is managed by the Theatre Program Manager.

Roles and Responsibilities

We are seeking a results-driven Technical Theatre Supervisor to serve as the resident technical expert and facility manager for our Bronx K-12 campus. This is not just a "behind-the-scenes" role; it is a leadership position that ensures our scholars perform in professional-grade environments. You will be responsible for the end-to-end technical execution of theatrical productions, high-stakes keynote events, and daily school-wide assemblies.

1. Technical Design & Production Execution
Lighting Design: Conceptualize, hang, circuit, and program lighting plots for all campus productions. Must be proficient in the ETC (Electronic Theatre Controls) ecosystem, including EOS-family consoles.
Sound Engineering: Manage live sound reinforcement and playback. This includes mic’ing performers, mixing live musical theatre/performances on Yamaha digital consoles, and maintaining signal chain integrity.
Multimedia & Projection: Oversee the integration of digital media, projection mapping, and QLab (or similar) workflows for performances and presentations.
Rigging & Safety: Maintain and operate theatrical rigging systems, ensuring all overhead equipment is secured and meets industry safety standards.
2. Asset Management & Operations
Preventative Maintenance: Establish a rigorous schedule for diagnosing, repairing, and maintaining all AV and stage equipment (lighting fixtures, wireless mics, cables, and scenic tools).
Inventory Control: Maintain a meticulously organized digital inventory of all technical assets. Oversee the procurement of expendables (gels, tape, batteries) and advise on long-term capital equipment upgrades.
Space Stewardship: Act as the "warden" of the auditorium; ensure the space is strike-ready after events and that all school-wide staff follow proper safety and equipment protocols.
3. Leadership & Collaboration
Cross-Functional Partnership: Collaborate with the School Operations Team to schedule space usage and ensure the technical needs of non-theatre events (Keynote speakers, graduations) are met.
Educational Support: Provide supplemental guidance and "on-the-job" training to theater teachers or scholars interested in the technical arts.
Rehearsal & Event Supervision: Manage the technical requirements of after-school rehearsals and performances, ensuring a professional atmosphere for scholars and staff.
Candidate Requirements
Technical Expertise
Professional Pedigree: Significant professional credit in technical theatre or a degree from a rigorous technical theatre program.
Console Mastery: Proven experience programming on ETC lighting boards and mixing on Yamaha digital sound boards is required.
Versatility: Ability to pivot from the "fine-tuning" of a lighting cue to the manual labor of assembly and maintenance.
Mindset & Leadership
The ETHOS Standard: You embody Excellence, Teamwork, Humor, Ownership, and Scholar-first decision-making.
High Agency: You don’t wait for things to break; you anticipate needs and "own" the results of the space.
Communication: You have the confidence to lead a room and the presence to represent the Arts program to school leadership.
Physical & Logistical Requirements
Valid Driver’s License: Required for potential travel between sites or picking up supplies.
Physicality: Ability to lift up to 40 lbs, climb ladders, and work in elevated spaces (grids/catwalks).
Flexibility: Availability for evening and occasional weekend hours to support the production calendar.

Exact compensation may vary based on skills and experience.

Compensation Range

$75,000 - $75,000 USD

About the project:

MADAMADAM is a full length play that explores what happens when a queer man returns to his deadhome - the one he no longer identifies or chooses as his own— in search of a reckoning.

title: RIFFRAFF NYC AND ROGUE THEATER FESTIVAL PLAYFEST: CALL FOR SUBMISSIONS: I’M IN LOVE WITH AN IMMIGRANT AUGUST SHOWCASE
description:
RiffRaff NYC
New York, NY
US

CONTACT NAME

Riff Raff
JOB DETAILS
DESCRIPTION



RiffRaff NYC and Rogue Theater Festival invite playwrights to submit original short plays for our fourth festival showcase, I’m In Love With An Immigrant.

We welcome stories that explore love in all its forms: romantic, familial, platonic, cultural, or community love. Plays should center immigrant experiences in America and highlight the emotional bonds that shape belonging, identity, and home.

Submission Guidelines

Length: Plays must run 15–20 minutes

Cast Size: No more than four actors on stage

Theme: Stories must center on immigrant experiences in America connected to the theme I’m In Love With An Immigrant

Production Responsibility: If accepted, playwrights are responsible for casting, securing a director, and coordinating rehearsals (RiffRaff NYC producers are happy to assist if needed)

Participation Fee: $250, payable only if the play is accepted

Performance Dates: August 10–16

Venue: American Theatre of Actors

Awards & Opportunities

At the conclusion of the showcase, a panel of judges will present:

Best Play

Best Original Script

Best Director

Outstanding Performance Awards (3 recipients) – Recognizing exceptional acting, regardless of gender

Rogue Theater Festival Production Award – One selected piece will be invited to fully produce their play with the Rogue Theatre Festival at The Flea Theatre in 2027, participation fee waived

This marks RiffRaff NYC’s second collaboration with Rogue Theater Festival, continuing our shared mission of uplifting bold, diverse theatrical voices.

✉️ How to Submit

Email your 15–20 minute script (PDF) and a brief playwright bio to:

RiffRaff NYC
📧 riffraff.nyc@gmail.com
Subject Line: I’m In Love With An Immigrant – [Play Title] – [Playwright Name]

Submission Deadline: April 1st (with a possible extension)

_______________________________________________________________________________________________________________

RiffRaff NYC is a New York–based theatre and film company dedicated to championing immigrant artists and global perspectives. Through festivals, showcases, and original productions, RiffRaff creates platforms for underrepresented voices while building an international artistic community in the heart of NYC.

Rogue Theater Festival is an independent New York theatre festival committed to supporting bold, original work from emerging and established artists. Known for fostering creative risk and providing production opportunities beyond the festival itself, Rogue helps new plays and artists grow their work on New York stages.

Please note if you sing or play any musical instruments.

The Equity video submission deadline is February 25th, 2026, at 5pm PT.

SEEKING:


The roles of Olivia, Viola and Sir Andrew have been precast.


[ORSINO AND AS CAST] Male-identifying. A man who doesn’t understand himself and maybe
doesn't even know there is a Self to understand. Growing up in a rarefied, privileged world has spun a cocoon of narcissism and self-indulgence around what is in fact a sensitive, highly intelligent, and kind man. Some part of him is dimly ready to be woken up.

[SEBASTIAN AND AS CAST] Male-identifying. Courageous, smart, compassionate. These qualities make him strangely attractive to everyone he meets. Sensitive to the point of being over-sensitive. Spontaneous and impulsive. His youth has the gift of accepting with complacent goodwill any situation as it comes, sometimes with an intense in-the-moment Presence, and sometimes with an infant’s lack of object-permanence.

[ANTONIO AND AS CAST] Male-identifying. Astonishingly brave, a little swashbuckling even. Has seen (and been the cause of) some horrifying violence, which out of love for Sebastian he dilutes or romanticizes, but the memory of and the potential for bloodshed are both there still. Loyal, capable of deep and utter devotion. Hopeless and even shy in his love for Sebastian, which he knows is not. returned and yet still is unable to help himself.

[MARIA AND AS CAST] Female-identifying. Intelligent, mischievous, merry, cheerful, always with a twinkle in the eye, and so she finds it very hard to endure Olivia’s enforced period of mourning. But she really is trying her best to be good. Salty and earthy, utterly in command. Like Toby, her joy and fun can turn mean on a dime, and she won’t lose a moment’s sleep over it. You might be laughing uproariously at something she’s just said only to suddenly realize the joke was on you.

[SIR TOBY BELCH AND AS CAST] Male-identifying. Immensely funny, witty, ranging from slapstick to deadpan. Occasionally cunning. Not a Falstaff, there is less expansiveness, less philosophy, more rapaciousness. Boisterous irresistible good humor and silliness that can turn into mean drunk quickly and unexpectedly. Never blustering, his improvisation is always masterful and in control. There’s a kind of desperateness in his insistent partying that partly comes from his addiction (like all addicts, he carries on long past the point of real pleasure) and partly is a kind of childish (but vital!) rebellion against Olivia’s mourning.

[MALVOLIO AND AS CAST] Any gender identity. Not a tyrannical gargoyle, not pinched and cruel, not joyless, not loveless. “Sad and civil”, which implies seriousness and self-control, but also empathy, or the capacity to hold space for others. Rather humorless, and they take their job very, *very* seriously. Their self-seriousness and rigorous application of themself to their work makes others see in them uppishness and pomposity (not totally unjustified), making them an easy and credulous target for cruel jokes. But from Malvolio's point of view, they're just doing their job (and doing it well) and they can’t understand why nobody else is doing theirs. Their aspiration for Olivia’s love is not entirely predatory/ambitious.

[FABIAN AND AS CAST] Any gender identity. An essentially un-serious person, laconic bordering on insolent, Tom Sawyer-ish in their desire to escape all work or responsibility. Very smart. Playing hooky is an art and being useless a philosophy. Their enjoyment of the sandbox/playground of life is infectious. If you’re planning a party you’d be like “Oh, know who would LOVE this? Fabian.” Witnessing the consequences of their actions is jarring for them.

[FESTE AND AS CAST] Any gender identity. Wise enough to play the fool. Something of the stray dog about them. Unashamed to sing for their supper but knows also how to keep some part of themself separate and unclaimed. Comfortable in any company because they are utterly at ease with being seen. Nothing to hide and nowhere to hide it anyway. Singing required.


SALARY

99 Seat Agreement $17.81 per hour

UNION

AEA

title: TECHNICAL DIRECTOR
description:
Full Stop Production Studio
Largo, FL
US

CONTACT NAME

Brandon Copeland
JOB DETAILS
DESCRIPTION

Position:

Full Stop Technical Director

Overview:

The Technical Director is responsible for working across the Full Stop brands with all team members, contractors, clients and IP holders. You will play a crucial role in overseeing and coordinating and leading all aspects of the technical production process. Your primary responsibility will be to ensure that each technical aspects of the project runs smoothly from conception to completion, meeting artistic standards, budgetary constraints, and deadlines. You will collaborate closely with directors, designers, technical staff, performers, venues, IP Holders, clients and producers to bring the technical creative vision to life while managing the logistical details and overall vision.

Reporting Structure:

The Technical Director will report directly to the Director of Production. As a key member of Full Stop Productions team, this position will collaborate closely with the co-owners, clients, employees, contractors, vendors, stake holders, producers, designers, and other Creative Team members to achieve departmental and organizational goals.

Key Responsibilities:

· Technical Planning and Scheduling:

· Work closely with technical and creative teams, producers, venue, IP Holder’s, clients and other stakeholders to understand and contribute to the creative vision and technical requirements for each production.

· Develop and coordinate the overall, build, install/strike, rehearsal and operations schedules and timelines.

· Manage scheduling conflicts and ensure efficient use of resources, including venue space, equipment, and personnel.

· Technical Production Oversight:

· Create and modify technical drawings, build drawings, take offs, install packages, mark ups, and documentation

· Collaborate with the creative team, designers, shops, IP Holder’s and clients to execute technical elements of the production, including but not limited to scenic, props, rigging, lighting, audio, video, costumes, special effects, automation and more.

· Coordinate and oversee the integration of all technical elements into each project.

· Troubleshoot technical issues during all phases of the production and ensure that all technical elements are properly planned, installed, maintained and operated.

· Budget Management:

· Working with the producers and clients to develop and manage technical and creative budgets.

· Create RFP’s, bid sheets, and negotiate contracts with vendors, suppliers, and personnel to ensure cost-effective solutions for the production without compromising artistic integrity and vision.

· Monitor expenses throughout the process and propose and implement cost-saving measures or value engineering when necessary and appropriate.

· Logistics and Operations:

· Plan, attend and run production meetings, site visits, shop visits, installs, rehearsals, shows, strikes and, events as needed as the Technical Director, travel will be required

· Coordinate all logistical aspects of the production, including transportation, trucking, shipping, storage, lodging, and catering.

· Manage and document the procurement process, maintenance plans and all technical documentation required for the smooth operation of the production including but not limited to all technical elements, rehearsals, install and strikes, operations and logistics.

· Ensure compliance with health and safety regulations throughout the technical process, identifying and addressing potential hazards.

· Team Coordination:

· Working with the producers, to hire and supervise additional technical staff and crew as needed for varying projects

· Foster a collaborative and positive working environment, ensuring effective communication and teamwork among all technical team members.

· Lead production meetings, builds, installs and strikes for various projects including live shows, parades, museums, marketing activations, conventions, and more.

· Provide guidance and support to team members, addressing any concerns or challenges that arise during build, installation, rehearsals, operations and strike.

· Business Development

· Work closely with the Executive Producers to secure and finalize business deals on behalf of the Full Stop brands.

· Assist in building long term relationships on behalf of the Full Stop brands with new and existing clients

· Promote the company’s products, services and make suggestions for opportunities and new development

Qualifications and Skills:

· Bachelor’s degree in Technical Theater Production, Arts Management, or related field (or 5+ years of equivalent professional experience).

· Proven experience in technical management (touring, theme park or cruise ships preferred), with a strong understanding of the technical process from concept to performance and a familiarity with technical aspects of theatrical production, including rigging, stagecraft, lighting, sound, video and scenic, automation and special effects.

· Excellent organizational and time management skills, with the ability to multitask and prioritize competing demands.

· Ability to interpret, review, and develop plans from technical drawings using AutoCAD; experience with Vectorworks or Rhino preferred but not required. Familiar with additional technical platforms including BIM workflows.

· Strong leadership, written and verbal communication skills, with the ability to effectively collaborate, lead and guide the production while working with diverse teams and stakeholders.

· Knowledge of budgeting and financial management principles, with experience managing and tracking technical budgets and expenses.

· Highly organized with strong problem-solving skills with the ability to interpret and draft instructions and notes in various formats and software including but not limited to technical drawings, bid sheets, contracts and other business and technical documents.

· Thrives in a fast-paced, dynamic environment, often under pressure and tight deadlines.

· Flexibility and adaptability to work in a variety of situations and conditions.

· In-depth knowledge of Microsoft Office, Asana, and file sharing platforms.

· Ability to work and live in Tampa Bay FL, with US Work Authorization

· Ability to travel worldwide for extended periods of time based on the technical needs of the production.

· Availability to work evenings, weekends, and holidays as required by technical schedules.

· Physical ability to lift and move heavy equipment and set pieces, walk and stand for extended periods of time.

title: SEEKING SINGERS/INSTRUMENTALISTS FOR OUTDOOR, SITE-SPECIFIC, NEW MUSICAL
description:
ECODISASTER Musical
Brooklyn , NY
US

CONTACT NAME

Madeline Wall
JOB DETAILS
DESCRIPTION


CONTRACT:
12 Rehearsals and 4 performances
$200 stipend
non-union

PREPARATION:
Please email us a video (or link to a video) of you singing. If you play an instrument, please send us a video of you playing it.
In your email, please briefly introduce yourself.
If you have a role(s) you're particularly interested in, please say so.

PERSONNEL:
Will review submissions:

Director, Madeline Wall
Music Director, Lily White
Book and Lyrics Writer, Sarah Safford
Composer, Sean Ivy

ABOUT THIS PROJECT:
EcoDisaster in the Hundred Acre Wood

New Musical

100 years ago Winnie the Pooh and his friends were introduced in an English magazine. Since then they have been endlessly adapted and taken on countless reimaginings by readers around the world. Now, Washington Park in Brooklyn takes up the role of the Hundred Acre Woods. The familiar characters are older and the Forest is under threat from the impacts of climate change and an encroaching pipeline project. We see Winnie the Pooh and friends co-existing in a somewhat neglected habitat, their ‘retirement community’. They lovingly bicker and exchange grievances about their situation.


We’re looking for actors with strong musicianship. For this upcoming May 2026 production, we’ve envisioned a site-specific show where actors play instruments in a jug band as they traipse around Old Stone House and Washington Park - transforming it into the 100 Acre Wood!


Songs will be led by guitar, banjo, and piano, accompanied by instruments like washtub bass, washboard, jugs, spoons, buckets, and bottles. If you have another instrument you love playing (Concertina? Flute? Violin? Tuba?), we’d love to find a way to incorporate it into the score.

The play explores themes of aging and disability. The reality of this production dictates that actors must be able to walk, as well as climb stairs. But we’d love to build a cast that reflects Brooklyn’s diversity of ages and abilities. If you have limited mobility or are differently abled, don’t hesitate to apply - we will accommodate.

The project is in continual development and has a long life ahead of it as a touring production through NYC and beyond. We want to find a cast that is excited by the material both for its elements of literary nostalgia surrounding the original Winnie the Pooh books, and for their urgent passion to engage with the current environmental landscape.

Listed vocal types are flexible, and we’re very willing to adjust music to fit the cast’s vocal range.


SEEKING



Band Leader
Plays piano, guitar, or banjo. Drives the music for most songs.
Uses props to make sound effects including rain and thunderstorms.
Plays the character of CR Jr, 40-50’s, corporate type in two scenes.
Voices Christopher Robin Sr. in prologue

Pooh
Tenor/Baritone.
Character is a man, aged 50-60, but could be played by any gender or age.
Pooh has a compassionate soft side. Portly and arthritic. Enjoys simple pleasures and has trouble with abstract thinking and seeing beyond his own immediate needs.
Instrumentalist a plus

Piglet
Tenor/Alto.
Character is a young gender fluid person, but could be played by any gender or age.
They are small, agile and fast moving. Suffers from generalized anxiety related to perceived outside threats, imaginary and real.
Instrumentalist a plus

Rabbit
Tenor/Baritone.
Character is a middle-aged man, but could be played by any gender or age.
High energy, overachiever and control freak. Needs to keep busy. Efficient to a fault and expects the same of others.
Instrumentalist a plus


Eeyore
Bass/Baritone.
Character is a young man, but could be played by any gender or age.
Slow moving and chronically depressed. His depression is often played for laughs - so an actor with a quick sardonic wit is a plus.
Instrumentalist a plus

Roo

Meso/Soprano.
Character is a young woman, but could be played by any gender or age.
Energetic and on the spectrum; mostly uninterested in the concerns of older animals. A gymnast, rapper, and generally fun person.
Instrumentalist a plus

Owl
Soprano
Character is a Woman, age 50-60, but could be played by any gender or age.
Elder, and occasionally wiser, member of the community, able to read and orate, interested in current events. Suffers from hearing, vision and memory loss, and anxiety related to aging and the news she reads about climate crisis.
Doubles as Engineer #3 - 40’s - any gender. Sensitive and dreamy. Loves nature and animals.
Dance/Movement ability is a plus.
Instrumentalist a plus.



Ensemble Track 1
Any age, any gender. Dancer or strong mover. Puppeteering experience is a plus. They help guide the audience around the park and create sound and visual effects to help tell the story.
Plays Engineer #1. 40-50’s Woman. Authoritative and defensive about her role in a non-traditional job.
Plays Grandchild #1 - Early teens. Internet trend obsessed and high energy. They deliver comic relief.
Instrumentalist a plus.

Ensemble Track 2
Any age, any gender. Dancer or strong mover. Puppeteering experience is a plus. They help guide the audience around the park and create sound and visual effects to help tell the story.
Plays Engineer #2. 20-30’s - Man. Very invested in proving himself.
Plays Grandchild #2 - Preteen. Internet trend obsessed and high energy. They deliver comic relief.
Instrumentalist a plus.

DURATION

Apr 12, 2026 - May 31, 2026

SALARY

$200 stipend

title: SEASONAL STAFF
description:
Greenbrier Valley Theatre
Lewisburg, WV
US
JOB DETAILS
DESCRIPTION

Seasonal Staff for Greenbrier Valley Theatre

We are looking for:

scenic painter/general technician

prop artisan/general technicial

head electrician

wardrobe assistant & summer camp TA

summer camp TA (shorter contract duration)

About Greenbrier Valley Theatre (GVT)

Greenbrier Valley Theatre is proud to be West Virginia’s State Professional Theatre, dedicated to producing high-quality live performances that enrich our community. Our 2026 season will consist of Ripcord, The Greenbrier Ghost, Tuesdays with Morrie, The Mousetrap, and Miracle on 34th Street: The Live Musical Radio Play and we are seeking creative and versatile employees to support both the technical and design aspects of our shows over a 8-month contract.


Key Responsibilities

Provide technical support during set construction, rehearsals, performances, and strikes, ensuring all equipment and stage elements are safely installed and maintained.

Assist in your department's execution of design elements according to production requirements and design specifications.

Collaborate with the Technical Director, directors, and design team to interpret design drawings and technical plans.

Maintain a clean, safe, and organized workshop and storage area for work and materials.

Monitor inventory and coordinate repairs or replacements as needed to support production demands.

Support load-ins, load-outs, and strikes during production runs, adapting to variable schedules that may include evenings, weekends, and peak production periods.

Work backstage as run crew for productions as assigned

Required Experience & Skills

Demonstrated experience in your desired department's skills, and/or general theatre production.

Proficiency in machine & hand sewing, carpentry, fabrication, and painting techniques with the ability to work with various materials. (as relevant to job type)

Ability to read and interpret technical drawings, and design plans.

Physical capability to lift, move, and construct sets and use of ladders & vertical mast lifts, including the ability to safely lift up to 50 lbs.

Strong problem-solving skills, attention to detail, and the ability to work both independently and collaboratively in a fast-paced environment.

Flexibility to work variable hours, including evenings and weekends as production schedules demand.

Be able to successfully pass a background check.

Preferred Experience & Skills

A degree in Theatre, Design, or a related field is preferred.

Experience working in a professional theatre environment.

Knowledge of modern prop fabrication techniques and materials.

Familiarity with safety protocols and best practices in a technical theatre setting.

Employment Details

Salary range for this position is $500 per week for the 8-month contract

Out of town seasonal hires receive a private bedroom with a shared bathroom, living and kitchen space within walking distance of the theatre. Housing is furnished, and basic kitchen supplies and bedding are provided. There is access to complimentary laundry facilities and wifi.

A travel stipend of $150 will be offered for this position.

The contract begins April 13, 2026 and concludes on December 22, 2026.

This is a full-time position requiring a variable schedule to meet production demands, including day, weekend, and evening hours. Compensation on a standard 40-hour work week. Overtime is paid in accordance with state and federal law with managerial approval.

US work authorization is required.

All seasonal employees must have a valid drivers license and reliable transportation.



Apply

Visit https://sites.google.com/gvtheatre.org/gvt-employment/ for more details on all available positions.

To apply, please email seasonalartistsprogram@gvtheatre.org and include the position you’re applying for in the subject line. We ask that you apply for one position only.

Your application should include a brief cover letter sharing your interest in the role, a current resume, and three professional references. While not required, applicants are welcome to include links to a portfolio or personal website if they feel it supports their application.

The deadline to apply is March 8, 2026 at 5 PM EST.

No phone calls, please.

$500.00 – $500.00 per week

title: ASSISTANT COMPANY MANAGER – BRASS JAR PRODUCTIONS/ DRUNK SHAKESPEARE
description:
Brass Jar Productions
Brooklyn, NY
US
JOB DETAILS
DESCRIPTION
Assistant Company Manager – Brass Jar Productions

Compensation: $55,000–$65,000 per year
Location: Remote (Strong preference for NYC, Chicago, DC, Phoenix, or Houston)
Work Schedule: Full time, 40 hours/week, primarily Mon–Fri
Start Date: Immediately

Brass Jar Productions, the team behind the hit comedy Drunk Shakespeare, is seeking a highly organized, detail-oriented Assistant Company Manager to support our growing national operations team.

As our company expands across multiple cities and productions, this role plays a critical part in ensuring our people systems, contracts, and documentation remain clear, compliant, and scalable. You’ll work closely with the National Company Manager and support leadership across venues to keep day-to-day operations running smoothly.

This is an excellent opportunity for someone who enjoys building systems, supporting managers, and working at the intersection of people, process, and live entertainment.

Who You Are

You’re an operations-minded professional who thrives on organization, follow-through, and clarity. You enjoy managing details, tracking moving pieces, and supporting teams across locations. You’re comfortable handling sensitive information, juggling multiple priorities, and communicating clearly with a wide range of stakeholders.

You’re not looking to be the loudest voice in the room — you’re looking to be the person who makes sure nothing falls through the cracks.

Must-Haves



2+ years of experience in company management, operations, HR administration, or a related role






Exceptional organizational skills and attention to detail






Strong written and verbal communication






Comfort working across multiple cities and time zones






Ability to manage confidential information with discretion






Proven ability to track deadlines, documentation, and workflows






Comfort reporting to senior leadership and supporting managers



Bonus Points



Experience in live entertainment, theatre, hospitality, or venue-based operations






Familiarity with union environments or collective bargaining agreements






Experience supporting large, distributed teams






Strong spreadsheet and documentation skills



What You’ll Do

The Assistant Company Manager supports the National Company Manager in maintaining the operational backbone of a multi-city live entertainment company.

Key responsibilities include:




Preparing and tracking cast, crew, and manager contracts






Supporting onboarding and offboarding processes across cities






Maintaining accurate records related to employment, agreements, and compliance






Assisting with CBA documentation, tracking, and updates






Serving as a first point of contact for routine manager questions






Coordinating paperwork, deadlines, and approvals across departments






Supporting process improvements to reduce administrative load and errors






Assisting with special projects related to staffing, systems, and operations




This role is operational and execution-focused, not creative or disciplinary.

What This Role Is (and Is Not)

This role is:




Hands-on and detail-driven






Supportive of managers and leadership






Central to maintaining consistency as the company scales




This role is not:




A creative or casting role






A scheduling decision-maker






A senior leadership position






An HR disciplinarian



Compensation & Benefits



$55,000–$65,000 annual salary (based on experience)






Company-sponsored health insurance (or equivalent stipend)






Paid time off






Complimentary tickets to Drunk Shakespeare






Opportunity to grow with a national, expanding live entertainment company



Location

This role is remote, but we strongly prefer candidates based in or near one of our current markets:
NYC, Chicago, DC, Phoenix, or Houston.

To Apply

Email jobs@brassjar.com with
[Your Name – Assistant Company Manager] in the subject line.

Please include:




A resume highlighting relevant experience






A brief note describing your interest in the role



About Us

Brass Jar Productions is the producer of Drunk Shakespeare, a critically acclaimed comedy playing in multiple cities across the U.S., blending classic literature with irreverent humor and immersive bar settings. We operate a growing portfolio of live productions and venues and are building the infrastructure to support our next phase of expansion.

Learn more at drunkshakespeare.com.
