title: PODCAST SOCIAL MEDIA PRODUCER
description:
Dream Three
New York, NY
US

CONTACT NAME

Jennifer Hanley
JOB DETAILS
DESCRIPTION

Please apply using the link:
https://jobs.ashbyhq.com/dreamthree/24b0c5a6-d77f-4d0b-a65e-e12824035e91?utm_source=Playbill

ROLE OVERVIEW

Dream Three multi-platform story studio creating content across film, TV, theater, audio, publishing, and immersive media. Our podcast division produces shows that spark cultural conversations—content for people who find community in the things they love.

We're looking for a Social Media Producer who doesn't treat social as an afterthought. You'll have a seat at the creative table working closely with producers, talent, and the production team from concept through delivery.

WHAT SUCCESS LOOKS LIKE IN THIS ROLE

• Social content that feels intentional, not extracted—because you shaped it upstream.

• A consistent, on-brand content calendar that publishes on time—every time.

• Clear trajectory toward 100K followers with documented learnings on what's working.

• A repeatable system where great podcast conversations naturally become great social content.

WHO YOU ARE

• You think in clips before anyone hits record. You're not just someone with ideas—you're someone who ships. You can pitch a concept in a planning meeting and have it posted by end of week.

• You move fast but care deeply about craft, community, and the details that make content feel authentic rather than algorithmic. You understand fandom and pop culture—not because you've studied it, but because you've lived it.

KEY RESPONSIBILITIES

• Creative Partnership: Work closely with producers and talent to shape content with social in mind from the start. Bring a social-first perspective to creative conversations.

• Content Production + Coordination: Manage a small team of short-form video editors. Create clear briefs with creative direction. Oversee timelines and ensure deliverables are on-brand and ready to post.

• Calendar + Execution: Own the social media calendar across all platforms. Coordinate releases with episode drops, guest promotions, and cultural moments. Ensure consistent, on-time publishing.

• Growth + Experimentation: Develop and test content formats, hooks, and series ideas. Track trends, sounds, and platform shifts. Iterate based on what's working.

• Analytics + Optimization: Track performance metrics and present clear weekly reports. Use data to inform creative decisions and editor direction.

ROLE REQUIREMENTS

• 2+ years in social media production, content creation, or a similar role (podcast, creator, or entertainment experience strongly preferred).

• Proven track record of executing—not just ideating. Show us things you've shipped.

• Deep fluency in short-form platforms (TikTok, Reels, Shorts) and what performs on each.

• Ability to give clear, constructive creative direction to editors.

• Strong instincts for hooks, pacing, and social-first storytelling.

• Highly organized—able to manage multiple deliverables without dropping balls.

• Genuine connection to fandom and pop culture. We can teach tools; we can't teach passion.

BONUS POINTS

• Experience working with talent on promotional content and social collaborations.

• Background in live events, conventions, or experiential content.

• Experience building or refining production workflows and systems.

• A personal fandom you're genuinely passionate about (we'll ask).

TOOLS YOU’LL USE

• Planning & Collaboration: Google Workspace, Slack, Zoom, Asana, Frame.io, Agorapulse

• Tracking: Airtable, Sheets

• File Sharing: Dropbox

THE DETAILS

• Hours: 15–20 hours/week to start, with flexibility to scale based on production cycles and live events.

• Location: Hybrid, with regular meetings in Manhattan.

• Travel: Occasional travel for events and content production.

• Contract: Initial 90-day evaluation period with potential for ongoing engagement.

• Compensation: Commensurate with experience.

• Start: Immediate availability preferred.

• Work Authorization: Must be legally authorized to work in the U.S.

DURATION

Feb 16, 2026 -

SALARY

$25.00 – $45.00 per hour
HOW TO APPLY
APPLY BY EMAIL

4c43682b-ad02-4a26-8f3c-684181a7c879…

When a gender is included in a character description, it refers only to the gender identity and/or presentation of that character as scripted by the playwright and not that of the performer

TICK, TICK...BOOM!
Director: Shawn Churchman
Musical Director: Aaron Jodoin
Rehearsals begin: June 15, 2026
Performances: June 25, 2026 - July 12, 2026

SYNOPSIS: Tick, Tick… Boom! follows Jonathan Larson, a young, fiercely driven composer racing against the clock as he approaches 30 and desperately tries to break into the New York theatre world before time—and his chances—run out. While juggling his diner job, a make-or-break workshop for his sci-fi musical, and the unraveling relationships with his girlfriend and best friend, Jonathan feels the pressure mounting from every direction. But when life delivers an emotional wake-up call, he discovers that the real ticking isn’t about career deadlines—it’s about love, loss, and the fire that pushes an artist to create against all odds.

SEEKING:


JONATHAN: (Male, 25 - early 30s) Dynamic, charismatic leading man. Struggling East Village
composer turning 30; smart and likeable, extremely passionate and determined; edgily ironic and irreverent and a little self-involved. Strong rock voice. Tenor. Vocal Range (middle C is C4): A2 – A4 (two octaves)

MICHAEL: (Male, 25 - early 30s) Jonathan's roommate and best friend. A gay business professional with an artist's soul. Career-minded and image-conscious but also supporting of and caring toward Jonathan. Soulful and devoted, but secretive. Doubles several additional character roles. Strong rock voice. Tenor. Vocal Range (middle C is C4): Bb2 – G4

SUSAN: (Female, 25 - early 30s) Jonathan's girlfriend. A compelling personality in her own right, she is both nurturing, loving and supportive but also growing increasingly frustrated with Jonathan's preoccupation and lack of commitment. This track doubles several additional character roles. A dancer. Mezzo-Soprano. Vocal Range (middle C is C4): Strong belt Ab3 to D5

INCIDENT AT OUR LADY OF PERPETUAL HELP
Director: Ginna Hoben
Rehearsals begin: July 13, 2026
Performances: July 23, 2026 - August 9, 2026

SYNOPSIS: Incident at Our Lady of Perpetual Help is a fast-paced, heartwarming comedic play that follows 19-year-old Linda O’Shea as she narrates the hilariously disastrous day when her attempt to give her younger sister “the talk” spirals completely out of control. Set in a tight-knit 1970s Irish Catholic community, the family’s private conversation is overheard by the parish’s most fearsome gossip, sending rumors flying and putting the O’Sheas’ reputation—and their sanity—on the line. As Linda tries to retell and reclaim the events of the day, with her family chiming in to correct her version of the story, the play becomes a joyful, chaotic celebration of family, faith, and the fine art of surviving small-town scandal.

SEEKING:

LINDA O’SHEA: (Female, 19-years old) Linda is highly intelligent, caring, and curious. She alternates between thinking she knows everything and thinking she knows nothing. Responsible and rarely impetuous.

JOSEPHINE ‘JO’ O’SHEA: (Female, late 40s, early 50s) Jo juggles more plates than Cirque de
Soleil. A great mom who defines multi-tasking. She's also a little more emotional and prone to
outbursts than usual because, well…you’ll see.

BECKY O’SHEA: (Female, 13-years old) Becky is an unusual child. Bright and verbal. Full of energy and a crazy-huge imagination. She speaks quickly, not unlike some of the characters in the movies she loves, like "His Girl Friday."

THERESA ‘TERRI’ CHARMICHAEL: (Female, late 50s) Terri is definitely going through a rough
patch, but she is not a depressive or phlegmatic. Think Thelma Ritter or Eve Arden, with a touch of Dorothy Parker. Fast talker.

TRACK 1: (Male, 50s) This track will double as three roles - Mike O’Shea (50s)/ Father Lovett (50s)/ Betty Heckenbach (50s): MIKE is loud, loyal, and single-task oriented. His definition of a father is: Breadwinner and disciplinarian. Lousy listener. / FATHER LOVETTT is an old school, Catholic priest. Egotistical, imperious, and pampered. Unused to any kind of pushback from parishioners or anyone else for that matter. / There is a BETTY HECKENBACH in everyone's life. She's right up there with death and taxes—only less fun. Even if the role is played by a man, it will be played absolutely straight—no winking or flamboyance. Just a homely, judgmental, middle-aged woman sticking her big puss into other people's business.

RING OF FIRE
Director: Michael Santora
Music Director: TBD
Rehearsals begin: August 10, 2026
Performances: August 20, 2026 - September 6, 2026

SYNOPSIS: Ring of Fire is a spirited, toe-tapping musical that celebrates the life, legacy, and music of Johnny Cash by threading together his greatest hits to tell a sweeping American story. Rather than following a traditional plot with one main character, the show uses a cast of performers to trace the arc of Cash’s journey—from humble beginnings in the Arkansas cotton fields, through love, struggle, faith, rebellion, heartbreak, and redemption—while capturing the grit, humor, and soul that defined him. Through iconic songs like “I Walk the Line,” “Folsom Prison Blues,” and “Ring of Fire,” the musical becomes a vibrant portrait of resilience and the power of music to carry us through every season of life.

SEEKING:

TRENNA: (Female, 20s-40s) Trenna functions as the primary female voice of the ensemble—warm, intuitive, and grounded. She often embodies the perspective of June Carter Cash, though not as a literal portrayal. Her presence brings emotional balance, humor, and vitality to the storytelling. She is capable of both tender vulnerability and playful charm, anchoring many of the show’s emotional arcs. Vocal Range: Flexible alto to mezzo; strong lead and harmony skills. Instruments: Acoustic guitar (preferred), basic percussion.

JASON: (Male, 20s-40s) Jason often carries central narrative threads tied to young Johnny Cash’s spirit—hopeful, yearning, searching. While not a direct impersonation, he channels youthful energy, earnest charm, and emotional clarity. He functions as one of the musical anchors of the ensemble and frequently leads transitions between thematic segments. Vocal Range: Tenor/baritone with strong lead capability. Instruments: Acoustic guitar, hand percussion, auxiliary percussion.

EDDIE: (Male, 20s-40s) Eddie embodies the raw drive and rock-leaning edge of Johnny Cash’s
influence. He often brings intensity, swagger, and musical grit to the ensemble. A dynamic presence, he helps fuel the show’s rhythmic engine and frequently leads the more energetic or heavily guitar-driven numbers. Vocal Range: Tenor/baritone with commanding lead voice. Instruments: Acoustic guitar, electric guitar, various percussion.

DAVID: (Male, 20s-40s) David is the ensemble’s multi-instrumental backbone, bringing texture, color, and authenticity to the musical landscape. He often embodies the show’s rural, roots-driven heart. His character presence tends to be calm, warm, and subtly humorous—someone who helps tie the ensemble together musically and emotionally. Vocal Range: Flexible tenor/baritone with strong harmonies. Instruments: Electric guitar, banjo, mandolin, fiddle.

MARK: (Male, 20s-40s) Mark provides the musical foundation—steady, grounded, resonant. He often embodies a storyteller or observer role, offering reflective warmth and a grounded presence within the ensemble. While not always the focal soloist, his contributions are essential to the show’s structure and feel. Vocal Range: Baritone/bass-baritone; strong blend and occasional solo lines. Instruments: Bass (upright preferred; electric acceptable).


SALARY

Independent Theatre Contract $480 weekly minimum - plus housing, travel

UNION

AEA

description:
BOND New York
New York, NY
US

CONTACT NAME

Brian Letendre
JOB DETAILS
DESCRIPTION
Why not use your down time to get your real estate license virtually and start making money to not only get you through these uncertain times but give you financial flexibility to enhance your skills. Voice lessons? New headshots? Self-Tapes? As a three time Broadway veteran, I'm here to tell you there is a solution. I’m here to share my journey from Broadway to Broker and how I have thrived in both so I never had to fall back on anything.

BOND New York truly provides a flexible, supportive environment needed for artists who are looking to have financial independence while pursuing a career in the arts. It doesn’t have to be one or the other!

Join me for my free virtual event Saturday, February 28th, 2026 at 5:00 PM EDT, to find out how you can have a parallel career in real estate without having to compromise your artistic pursuits. I'm doing it…so can you!

title: SCENIC PROJECTION DESIGNER FOR AN ORIGINAL SHOW, SPIRIT OF THE GAME: THE ULTIMATE MUSICAL - MAY 14-17 IN NYC
description:
Ultimate Musical LLC
New York, NY
US

CONTACT NAME

Philip Vlahakis
JOB DETAILS
DESCRIPTION

Spirit of the Game: The Ultimate Musical is seeking a Scenic Projection Designer to join our creative team for a non-equity showcase production at Asylum NYC. Rehearsals begin April 22, 2026 and run each weekday from 10 am to 3 pm through May 8. Tech and dress rehearsals are planned for May 12 and 13 with performances running May 14-17. The Scenic Projection Designer would join production meetings before the start of the rehearsal schedule for planning and initial design discussions, and be available for some portion of the rehearsal schedule to adapt and refine designs given the developmental nature of this new work. This new musical blends athleticism, humor, and heart, and we’re looking for a designer who can help build a dynamic visual world through projection including scenes on the island of Crete in Greece and athletic fields in different locations where the sport of ultimate frisbee will come to life.




Responsibilities include:

Designing and implementing scenic projections that support storytelling, tone, and pacing
Collaborating closely with the director, lighting designer, and creative team
Developing projection concepts for environments, transitions, and stylized moments of play and motion
Preparing and delivering all projection media and documentation for rehearsals and tech
Participating in production meetings, rehearsals as needed, and technical rehearsals

Qualifications:

Experience designing projections for theatre, dance, or live performance
Strong visual storytelling skills and a collaborative working style
Proficiency with projection design software and media workflows (e.g., QLab, Isadora, After Effects, or similar)
Ability to work within production timelines and adapt to evolving creative needs
Interest in movement-driven or athletic performance a plus

Please submit a brief cover note and portfolio or samples of relevant work to info@ultimatemusical.com

Join us in bringing this high-energy, original musical to life through bold and imaginative projection design.
DURATION

Mar 2, 2026 - May 17, 2026

SALARY

$2,000.00 – $2,000.00 per gig
HOW TO APPLY
APPLY BY EMAIL

BREAKDOWN

Maine State Music Theatre 2026 Season




HAIRSPRAY – THE MUSICAL

Book by: Thomas Meehan and Marc O’Donnell

Music by: Marc Shaiman

Lyrics by: Marc Shaiman and Scott Wittman

Based on the New Line Cinema film, written and directed by John Waters

Director & Choreographer: Kenny Ingram

Music Director: David Fiorello

First Rehearsal for MSMT: May 29, 2026

Opening: June 4, 2026

Closing: June 20, 2026


Note: This show is a co-production with Fulton Theatre Company, Lancaster, PA. This production is fully cast, and we are not seeking performers for HAIRSPRAY at this EPA.


Tracy Turnblad - ROLE IS CAST. Our story's unsuspecting protagonist. Confident, talented, and incredibly determined. A romantic with a good heart and desire to cut up the dance floor. Always on top of the latest trends. Tracy Turnblad is a young lady with big hair and an even bigger personality!She is the hero of our story, and she is sweet but also strong in her convictions. She is bigger in size than the other girls, but she isn't shy about it - she can still dance with the best of them! An excellent singer and dancer, who has wonderful stage presence and can easily capture the audience's hearts.18+ to play high school age, white. Gender: Female Presenting. Mezzo-Soprano With a StrongTheatre/Pop Belt. Vocal range top: G5. Vocal range bottom: G3

Corny Collins - ROLE IS CAST. The charismatic host of the Corny Collins' Show. Good looking and smooth talking, he is a genuinely nice guy both on and off camera. 25 – 35, white. Gender: Male Presenting. Strong Pop Singer, High Baritone. Vocal range top: A4. Vocal range bottom: D3

Edna Turnblad - ROLE IS CAST. Tracy's big and blonde mother. She is a working housewife who has lost her confidence and dream to be a plus-size clothing designer. Boisterous and commanding. Often played by a male presenting performer. 40 – 55, white. Gender: Male Presenting. Bass-Baritone. Vocal range top: G5. Vocal range bottom: F3

Penny Pingleton - ROLE IS CAST. Tracy's best friend and dorky sidekick. Not the brightest girl, but she has good intentions. Bursting to get free of her mother's dominating control, she falls for Seaweed with childlike curiosity. 18+ to play high school age, white. Gender: Female Presenting. Strong High Belt, Contemporary Theatre/Pop Voice. Vocal range top: G5. Vocal range bottom: A3

Velma Von Tussle - ROLE IS CAST. Amber's mother and the director of Corny Collin's show. She is a devious taskmaster and snobby racist. The former Miss Baltimore Crabs will go to any length to ensure her daughter is the next big thing. 45 – 55, white. Gender: Female Presenting. Mezzo-Soprano With Strong Belt Mix. Vocal range top: E5. Vocal range bottom: G3

Amber Von Tussle - ROLE IS CAST. Link's girlfriend and Tracy's nemesis. She is pretty, shallow, snobby, and racist. Can't dance but is expected to win Miss Baltimore Hairspray. Always feels the need to be the center of attention. Female, 18+ to play high school age, white. Gender: Female Presenting. Mezzo-Soprano. Vocal range top: F5. Vocal range bottom: A3

Link Larkin - ROLE IS CAST. The star heartthrob on Corny Collins' show. He is extremely attractive and talented. Hoping to get his big break with a recording contract, he unexpectedly falls for Tracy. 18+ to play high school age, white. Gender: Male Presenting. Tenor With Strong Falsetto. Vocal range top: A5. Vocal range bottom: G3

Seaweed J. Stubbs - ROLE IS CAST. Tracy's classmate and friend, who is discriminated against due to his skin color. He is cocky but surprisingly lovable. Talented in song and dance. He falls for Penny. 18+ to play high school age, Black. Gender: Male Presenting. Excellent Soulful, Pop Singer - High Tenor. Vocal range top: D5. Vocal range bottom: F3


Little Inez - ROLE IS CAST. Seaweed's little sister. 18+ to play early teens, Black. Gender: Female Presenting. Soulful Voice with Strong Belt Mix. Vocal range top: F5. Vocal range bottom: G3

Motormouth Maybelle - ROLE IS CAST. Seaweed and Little Inez's mother, she also appears as the Guest DJ on the Corny Collin's Negro Day show. Big, blonde, beautiful and proud of it. She is sassy and confident. 40 – 50, Black. Gender: Female Presenting. Alto With High Belt. Vocal range top: E5. Vocal range bottom: F3

Wilbur Turnblad - ROLE IS CAST. Tracy's simpleminded and kind father. He owns a joke shop andsupports his daughter in spite of everything else. He also loves his wife, Edna, very much. 40 – 55, white. Gender: Male Presenting. Baritone With Strong Falsetto. Vocal range top: A5. Vocal range bottom: A3

Prudy Pingleton - ROLE IS CAST. Penny's strict mother. Very conservative, controlling, and closed minded. 40 – 55, white. Gender: Female Presenting. Mezzo-Soprano With Character Belt. Vocal range top: B4. Vocal range bottom: D4




1776

Book by Peter Stone

Music & Lyrics by Sherman Edwards

Based on a concept by Sherman Edwards

Director: Amber Mak

Choreographer: Christopher Page-Sanders

Musical Director: Jason Wetzel

First Rehearsal: June 6, 2026

Opening: June 25, 2026

Closing: July 11, 2026


SEEKING:

JOHN ADAMS: ROLE IS CAST. SEEKING UNDERSTUDY ONLY. Delegate from Massachusetts. John is a dutiful husband. Opinionated, passionate, and a bit boisterous, he wears his age with pride. Starving for independence from England. Gender: Male Presenting. Age: 35 -50. Vocal range top: F#4. Vocal range bottom: C3

ROGER SHERMAN: Delegate from Connecticut. A coffee drinker with a penchant for hyperactivity, Sherman is a simple and balding cobbler. Gender: Male Presenting. Age: 50-60. Vocal range top: Bb4. Vocal range bottom: C3

ROBERT LIVINGSTON: Delegate from New York. Recently a father, Livingston's disposition has become one of humility and graciousness. He has changed considerably over the years. Gender: Male Presenting. Age: 25-35. Vocal range top: F4. Vocal range bottom: Bb2

BENJAMIN FRANKLIN: Delegate from Pennsylvania. Franklin is intelligent, well-traveled, and pleasantly cunning. A jolly and admirable fellow with whom one would desire to have a friendship. Gender: Male Presenting. Age: 60 to 70. Vocal range top: Eb4. Vocal range bottom: Ab2

JOHN DICKINSON: ROLE IS CAST. SEEKING UNDERSTUDY ONLY. Delegate from Pennsylvania. A thin, hawkish gentleman. He is sharp-tongued and a touch detestable. Gender: Male Presenting. Age: 30 - 45. Vocal range top: E4. Vocal range bottom: A2

RICHARD HENRY LEE: ROLE IS CAST. SEEKING UNDERSTUDY ONLY. Delegate from Virginia, Lee is a willowy aristocrat. His flamboyancy is intoxicating and borderline infuriating. Gender: Male Presenting. Age: 40 - 55. Vocal range top: G4. Vocal range bottom: C3

THOMAS JEFFERSON: Delegate from Virginia. Though noticeably tall, Jefferson is mild-mannered and sweet. Along with being a well read man, he is very much in love with his wife. Gender: Male Presenting. Age: 25 - 35. Vocal range top: G4. Vocal range bottom: C3

EDWARD RUTLEDGE: Delegate from South Carolina. Despite his good looks, Rutledge is haunting and somewhat ominous as the youngest member of the Continental Congress. There is a serpent-like quality to him. Gender: Male Presenting. Age: 25 - 35. Vocal range top: A4. Vocal range bottom: C3

ABIGAIL ADAMS: Loving wife to John Adams. Intelligent, quick-witted, and talented with a pen, Abigail is a radiant and shapely beauty. Every bit as bright as her husband. Gender: Female Presenting. Age: 25 - 35. Vocal range top: F5. Vocal range bottom: Db4

DR. JOSIAH BARTLETT: Delegate from NH. Bartlett practiced medicine for over 40 years. During that time, he promoted wellness practices, including diet, exercise, fresh air, and a contented mind. Gender: Male Presenting. Age: 40s Vocal Range: Any

SAMUELA CHASE: Delegate from MD. Nicknamed Old Bacon Face due to his proneness for a facial flush when angered or excited or due to his general ruddy complexion, or both. Gender: Male Presenting. Age: 30s. Vocal Range: Any

DR. LYMAN HALL: Delegate from GA. Born in CT, graduated from Yale; physician, clergyman, statesman. Gender: Male Presenting. Age: 40s. Vocal Range: Any

JOHN HANCOCK: President of the Congress, from MA. He was one of the wealthiest men in the Colonies. He began his political career in Boston as a protégé of Samuel Adams. Gender: Male Presenting. Age: 40s. Vocal Range: Any

JOSEPH HEWES: Delegate from NC. Born in Princeton to Quaker parents. A shipping merchant, appointed to the Naval Board and the Marine Committee, which laid the foundation for the US Navy. Gender: Male Presenting. Age: 30s - 40s. Vocal Range: Any

STEPHEN HOPKINS: Male Presenting. 60+. Delegate from Rhode Island. Hopkins' drinking has led to an appearance befitting of the 2nd oldest in the Continental Congress. He has a dirty old man playfulness about him. Vocal range: C3–Eb4.

COL. THOMAS MCKEAN: Male Presenting. 40s. Delegate from Delaware. McKean is florid and likable with a charming, yet commanding, Scottish brogue. Vocal range: C3–Eb4.

MARTHA JEFFERSON: Female Presenting. 20s. Thomas Jefferson's very-much-in-love wife. Her looks are striking, her dancing delightful, and her humor appealing. She doesn't shy away from a good time. Joy radiates from her. Vocal range: Bb3–D5.

COURIER: Male Presenting. 20s. Any ethnicity. The message runner between General Washington's army and the Continental Congress. He has witnessed the hardships of war firsthand, although his innocent disposition and appearance may imply otherwise. Vocal range: C3–Db4.

LEWIS MORRIS: Male Presenting. 30s. Delegate from NY. Morris was born at his politically connected family's estate, Morrisania, presently part of Bronx County.

REV. JOHN WITHERSPOON: Male Presenting. 50s. Delegate from NJ. A Scottish American Presbyterian minister, educator, farmer, and slaveholder, he embraced the concepts of Scottish common-sense realism. President of the College of New Jersey, he was influential in the development of the United States’ national character.

JAMES WILSON: Male Presenting. 30s. Delegate from PA. Born in Scotland, he was a legal scholar, jurist, and statesman. A leading legal theorist, he was one of the first four Associate Justices appointed to the Supreme Court by George Washington.

CAESAR RODNEY: Male Presenting. 40s–50s. Delegate from DE. He was an officer of the Delaware militia during the French and Indian War and the American Revolutionary War. He was tormented throughout his life by asthma, and his adult years were plagued by a facial cancer.


GEORGE READ: Male Presenting. 40s. Delegate from DE. Described as “tall...gracefully formed, with pleasing features and lustrous brown eyes. His manners were dignified.... He commanded entire confidence.” Also, “his legal abilities are said to be very great, but his powers of oratory are fatiguing and tiresome to the last degree; his voice is feeble and his articulation so bad that few can have patience to attend him.”

CHARLES THOMSON: Male Presenting. 40s. Secretary of the Congress. Irish born, a Latin teacher and translator. As secretary, Thomson chose what to include in the official journals of the Continental Congress (which caused some criticism and disputes).

ANDREW MCNAIR: Male Presenting. 60s. Congressional custodian. Served as official ringer of the Liberty Bell from 1759 to 1776, and he likely rang it to announce independence on July 8.

LEATHER APRON / PAINTER: Male Presenting. 20s. A working man.




FROZEN

Music & Lyrics by Kristen Anderson-Lopez & Robert Lopez

Book by Jennifer Lee

SEEKING:

Elsa: Future Queen of Arendelle and Anna’s older sister; born with magical powers, isolates herself from others out of fear. Gender: Female Presenting. Age: Mid 20s – Early 30s. Vocal range top: Eb5. Vocal range bottom: E3

Anna: Princess of Arendelle and Elsa’s younger sister; an eternal optimist who longs to be loved and to connect with other people. Gender: Female Presenting. Age: Early 20s – Mid 30s. Vocal range top: E5. Vocal range bottom: G3

Kristoff: Hardworking ice harvester with a prickly exterior that hides a big heart. Gender: Male Presenting. Age: 20s – 30s. Vocal range top: Bb4. Vocal range bottom: A2

Hans: Prince of the Southern Isles and youngest of thirteen brothers; charming and ambitious. Gender: Male Presenting. Age: Mid 20s – 30s. Vocal range top: A4. Vocal range bottom: A2

Olaf: ROLE IS CAST. SEEKING UNDERSTUDY ONLY. Magical snowman with a childlike innocence. Gender: Any Gender. Age: 20s – 40s. Vocal range top: Eb5. Vocal range bottom: E3

Sven: ROLE IS CAST. SEEKING UNDERSTUDY ONLY. Kristoff’s fiercely loyal reindeer best friend. Gender: Any Gender. Age: 20s – 40s

Weselton: Duke from a neighboring kingdom; chauvinistic, impolite, and judgmental. Gender: Male Presenting. Age: 30s -50s. Vocal Range Top: A4. Vocal Range Bottom: F3

Young Anna: ROLE IS CAST. Younger princess of Arendelle with youthful exuberance; fun-loving troublemaker; mesmerized by her sister’s magic. Gender: Female Presenting. Age: 7 to 10 years old. Vocal range top: E5. Vocal range bottom: Bb3

Young Elsa: ROLE IS CAST. Elder princess of Arendelle with magical powers; obedient daughter; protective sister. Gender: Female Presenting. Age: 9 -12 years old. Vocal range top: E5. Vocal range bottom: A3




COME FROM AWAY

Book, Music, and Lyrics by Irene Sankoff & David Hein

Director: Mark Johnson

Choreographer: Kelly Bolick

Musical Director: Harry Collins

First Rehearsal: July 18, 2026

Opening: August 6, 2026

Closing: August 22, 2026


SEEKING:

Claude & others: ROLE IS CAST. SEEKING UNDERSTUDY ONLY. The gregarious and well-liked Mayor of Gander, Newfoundland, Claude loves his work, the townspeople and his daily traditions, but he's never had to deal with a crisis of this magnitude before. Doubles as Derm and Brenda’s Brother, Eddie. Gender: Male Presenting. Age: 40 to 60. Vocal range top: G4. Any Ethnicity

Bonnie & others: A no-nonsense mother of three, Bonnie is the head of the Gander area SPCA. When she discovers animals are trapped on the planes, she stops at nothing to ensure their safety - but in frustration, she often lashes out at those around her. Doubles as Martha. Gender: Female Presenting. Age: 30 to 40. Vocal range top: B4. Any Ethnicity

Beulah & others: ROLE IS CAST. SEEKING UNDERSTUDY ONLY. The head of the Gander Legion, with a firefighter son, who walks Hannah to her church and prays with her. Doubles as Delores. Gender: Female Presenting. Age: 40 to 60. Vocal range: Mezzo with belt up to D. Any Ethnicity

Oz & others: The quirky constable in the two-person Gander police force. When the town's population suddenly doubles, Oz helps out in unexpected ways. Doubles as Joey, Customs Officer, Mr. Michaels, Terry, Matty, Rabbi, and Head Cardiologist. Gender: Male Presenting. Age: 30 to 50. Vocal range top: G4. Any Ethnicity

Janice & others: An eager new local TV reporter, Janice is thrown into the deep end on her first day. Initially naïve about the world, Janice must face the pain and confusion around her. Doubles as Britney and Flight Attendant. Gender: Female Presenting. Age: 20 to 30. Vocal range top: E5. Any Ethnicity

Beverly/Annette & others: Beverly: The first female captain for American Airlines Pilot, Beverly Bass has always loved flying, when her world suddenly changes. Annette: A schoolteacher at Gander Academy with an active fantasy life. Doubles as Reporter. Gender: Female Presenting. Age: 50 to 60. Vocal range top: C#5. Any Ethnicity

Diane & others: A traditional divorcee from Texas, who is terrified that her son may have been flying at the time of the attacks. When she finds out that he's safe, she's given a new lease on life and discovers a wilder more carefree side of herself. Doubles as Crystal and Brenda. Gender: Female Presenting. Age: 50 to 60. Vocal range top: C#5. Vocal range bottom: A3. Any Ethnicity

Nick/Doug & others: Nick: An English oil engineer who is focused on his work, Nick's life is turned upside down when he falls for Diane. Doug: An Air Traffic Controller, married to Bonnie, who tries to help his wife and the animals. Doubles as Officer Stephenson, and Male Townsperson. Gender: Male Presenting. Age: 50 to 60. Vocal range top: E4. Any Ethnicity

Kevin T/Garth & others: Kevin T: The head of an environmental energy company in Los Angeles, Kevin was on vacation with his boyfriend (and secretary, also named Kevin), when they are stranded in Gander. Inspired by the town's generosity, Kevin creates the Pay It Forward Foundation. Garth: The head of the local union, representing the Bus Drivers. Doubles as President Bush. Gender: Male Presenting. Age: 30 to 50. Vocal range top: G4. Any Ethnicity

Kevin J/Ali & others: Kevin J: Kevin's boyfriend and secretary. Sarcastic and unhappy, he wants to leave as soon as possible. Ali: An Egyptian man traveling to America who experiences isolation and Islamophobia but who finds a connection to Beulah. Doubles as Dwight. Gender: Male Presenting. Age: 30 to 50. Vocal range: B2-G4. Middle Eastern

Hannah & others: ROLE IS CAST. SEEKING UNDERSTUDY ONLY. The mother of a firefighter in Manhattan, Hannah waits for news about her son and is comforted by Beulah. Doubles as Margie and Mickey. Gender: Female. presenting. Age: 40 to 60. Vocal range top: E5. Black

Bob & others: A hardened New Yorker, Bob is suspicious of where he's landed, fearing that it's World War 3, that someone is going to shoot him and steal his wallet - but instead, he ends up losing his New York jadedness. Doubles as Muhumuza and Captain Bristol. Gender: Male Presenting. Age: 20 to 40. Vocal Range: B2-F#4. Black

CONTRACT

Independent Theatre Contract

SEEKING

Equity actors for roles in ROMEO AND JULIET (see breakdown).

About the production: Set in 1968, at the height of the Vietnam War and nationwide civil unrest, this reimagining of Romeo and Juliet places the Capulets and Montagues on opposite sides of a fractured America. The Capulets are Hawks—aligned with authority, tradition, and the war machine—while the Montagues are Doves, rooted in protest culture, resistance, and the push for social change. Against a backdrop of demonstrations, generational rupture, and escalating violence, Romeo and Juliet’s love becomes an act of defiance—exposing the human cost of ideological extremism and asking whether empathy can survive when a nation is at war with itself.

New Canon Theatre Co. welcomes submissions from actors of all backgrounds, identities, and experiences. Character descriptions serve as guides for this production concept. We encourage all artists to submit for roles that interest them.

BREAKDOWN

WEST SIDE STORY

All roles will be understudied.


SEEKING:

THE JETS:

[TONY] 18+ to play teen, Tenor (Bb2 – Bb4), White. The restless leader of the Jets, now looking for a new life. Sentimental enough to fall in love with Maria, but still believably angry enough to kill Bernardo. Passionate, playful, poetic, impulsive.

[RIFF] 18+ to play teen, Bari-tenor (Bb2 – G4), White. Tony’s best friend and fellow member of the Jets. Looking for security and family in the gang, plays in harmony with Tony. Struggling with the fact that things are changing. Athletic, sexy, a bit of a bully. Must be a strong dancer.

[ACTION] 18+ to play teen, Tenor (G2 – D5), White. Member of the Jets. Young and hot-headed, quick to anger and always ready for a fight. Unpredictable loose cannon who tries to mask his sensitive side with violence. Must be a strong dancer.

[ANYBODYS] 18+ to play teen, Alto, White. A spunky tomboy who is desperate to become a member of the Jets. The other Jets mock her for her ambitions but generally appreciate her company. Full of energy and heart. Must be a strong dancer.

[BABY JOHN] 18+ to play teen, Tenor, White. The youngest and most sensitive member of the Jets. Must be a strong dancer.

[A-RAB] 18+ to play teen, Baritone, White. Baby John’s best friend. Loyal with a mischievous streak and a sharp sense of humor. Must be a strong dancer.

[DIESEL] 18+ to play teen. Baritone, White. Riff’s second-in-command. Physically imposing. Becomes the leader of the Jets after Riff’s death. Must be a strong dancer

[BIG DEAL] 18+ to play teen, Baritone, White. A loudmouth who’s always ready to jump into trouble, often getting hurt but never backing down. Must be a strong dancer.

[SNOWBOY] 18+ to play teen, Tenor or Baritone, White. A wisecracking, rebellious member of the Jets. Must be a strong dancer.

[GEE-TAR] 18+ to play teen, Tenor or Baritone, White. A loyal friend and member of the Jets. Must be a strong dancer


THE SHARKS:

[MARIA] 18+ to play teen, Lyric soprano (Bb3 – C6.), Latina. Young naïve newcomer to America. Falls in love with Tony, willing to see the person beyond the gang leader. Romantic and sensitive, but also willful. Determined and direct, with a compelling authentic presence.

[ANITA] 20s, Mezzo belt (F3 – D5), Latina. Maria’s best friend and Bernardo’s girlfriend. Fighting for her place in the world and wants to enjoy life. Outspoken, street-smart, magnetic and confident. Devoted and protective, understands limits. Must be excellent dancer and singer.

[BERNARDO] 20s, Baritone (Bb2 – Eb4), Latino. Maria’s brother and Anita’s boyfriend. Leader of the Sharks. Fiercely proud, quick-tempered, protective of his family. Charismatic and cool but burning inside. Must be a strong dancer.

[CHINO] 18+ to play teen, Latino. Angry and, at times, naive Shark who turns murderous and vengeful. Suitor to Maria and friend of Bernardo's. Must be a strong dancer.


THE ADULTS:

[DOC] 50s – 60s. The owner of the candy store where the Jets hang out. He tries to guide the Jets youthful angst and provides a safe haven for Tony. Old fashioned and wise in his ways. Non-singing role.

[SCHRANK] 40s – 50s. A local police detective frustrated by the ongoing violence between the Jets and Sharks. Blunt, brash, and unapologetic. Non-singing role.

[KRUPKE] 40s – 50s. The local beat cop. He has no patience for the gang conflict and tries to keep tensions from erupting between them. Regularly mocked by the local gangs. Non-singing role.

[GLAD HAND] 40s – 50s. Nerdy, overly cheerful, and ill-equipped social director at the school dance. Non-singing role.

SALARY

COST $1214 weekly minimum (Tier 4)

UNION

AEA

title: AUTOMATION TECHNICIAN - EXPRESSION OF INTEREST
description:
Hale Centre Theatre
Sandy, UT
US
JOB DETAILS
DESCRIPTION

SUMMARY
Hale Centre Theatre is building a pool of experienced automation professionals interested in operating and maintaining our state-of-the-art Automation systems for our award-winning productions.

Our Automation team supports multiple venues and collaborates closely with creative and technical departments to deliver safe, innovative, and technically seamless live performances. Team members work with advanced stage machinery and show control technology in a fast-paced, production-driven environment that values precision, training, and continuous improvement.

This posting is intended to identify and connect with qualified candidates for future openings within our Automation Department.

RESPONSIBILITIES
As a full-time Automation Technician, you will be an integral part of the Automation team, responsible for operating and maintaining automated show elements and control systems within the theaters at the Mountain America Performing Arts Center for Hale Centre Theatre. Your duties will include operating automation consoles during performances and performing automation maintenance tasks such as inspecting scenery and rigging, assisting with show installations, supporting special projects, and conducting preventative maintenance.

ESSENTIAL DUTIES AND RESPONSIBILITIES

Operate the automation control console in a safe and consistent manner for performances, performer/technician training, and maintenance operations.
Complete all required documentation such as pre-show checklists as directed.
Report issues occurred during performances in applicable logs and/or designated reporting methods.
Assist with maintenance and routine safety inspections on automation equipment and systems.
Assist with rigging tasks and projects during show strikes and installations.
Develop a thorough knowledge of all Automation Department equipment.
Participate in department trainings and development processes.
Troubleshoot electrical, software, and mechanical problems should they arise.
Work with other technical departments to maintain safety policies and procedures for maintenance, training, performer rescues, and performances.
Perform other duties assigned by HCT leadership.
EDUCATION, EXPERIENCE AND SKILLS REQUIRED
2+ years of operational experience with theatrical automation systems. (TAIT Navigator is a bonus).
2+ years of experience working and/or maintaining large-scale theatrical productions.
1+ years of experience working with theatrical rigging elements.
Bachelor's Degree or equivalent experience in automation, theatre or a related field.
Understanding of the various elements of the theatre process – production, technical and performance.
Excellent written and verbal communication skills. Knowledge and usage of correct English grammar, spelling, and punctuation.
Strong organizational and administrative skills – detail oriented.
Ability to problem-solve and facilitate solutions to issues.
Ability to learn quickly and adapt rapidly when required.
Ability to work productively under time pressures and meet deadlines.
Ability to work independently and exercise excellent decision-making skills.
High level of computer proficiency with knowledge of word processing, spreadsheets.
Works well in a stressful environment with many personality types.
Ability to work long hours and to manage an irregular schedule including weekends and holidays.
Proven ability to work independently and collaboratively in a fast paced, rapidly changing environment.
Ability to work in an active team environment.
Willingness to learn and grow.
Ability to lift 50lbs+.
Ability to work at heights of 75ft+.
PREFERRED EXPERIENCE AND SKILLS
TAIT Navigator Automation Software operating and/or programming experience.
Experience operating and/or programming performer flying systems.
Basic knowledge of Siemens or Beckhoff PLC, IO, & control systems pertaining to automated stage machinery.

Hourly compensation commensurate with experience. Individual compensation packages are based on various factors unique to each candidate, including skill set, experience, and qualifications

SALARY

$33.00 – $36.50 per hour
HOW TO APPLY
APPLY ONLINE

https://careers.hct.org/apply/oSsoTWgeP1/Automation-Technician-Expression-Of-Interest

title: THE HOMOSEXUALS, BY PHILIP DAWKINS (OUT/PLAY)
description:
OUTPLAY
New York, NY
US
JOB DETAILS
DESCRIPTION
THE HOMOSEXUALS, by Philip Dawkins.
Directed by Christopher Basile. Produced by OUT/PLAY.

To be performed under the Equity Showcase Code for this production. Both AEA and Non-Equity performers are encouraged to apply.

Actors will receive a $100 total stipend for rehearsals and performances.

IMPORTANT DATES:

Callbacks: Sunday, February 15

Table Read and Rehearsals Begin: Sunday, February 22

Performances:
Friday, April 3, 2026 at 7PM;
Saturday, April 4 at 7PM;
Sunday, April 5 at 3PM;
Sunday, April 5 at 7PM (possible addition);
Friday, April 10, 2026 at 7PM;
Saturday, April 11 at 7PM;
Sunday, April 12 at 3PM;
Sunday, April 12 at 7PM (possible addition)

CHARACTER BREAKDOWN:

The play begins in 2010 and runs backward until the final scene which takes place in 2000. So, the first scene of the play is the last chronologically (eg: in the first scene of the play, Evan is 29, and in the last scene, he is 20).

Peter: (Man; mid 40s, to play age 48 and 38) Artistic director of a prominent American regional theatre. Overtly and unapologetically flamboyant. If you cut him, he would bleed glitter. At the end of the play, Peter is in a long-term relationship with Mark. At the start of the play, he is dating Evan.

British Mark: (Man; mid/late 30s, to play age 38 and 31) A lawyer. Best friends with Collin, whom he met while at University in England (where—it hopefully goes without saying—he is from). British Mark is dependable without being a martyr, attractive without much trying, and kind without being nice. Incredibly charming and often impulsive. Actor will be in their underwear and in sexual situations with another actor.

Tam: (Woman, early/mid 30s, to play age 32 and 28) When we first see her, Tam is a 5th grade teacher at an inner-city “at risk” school. At the end of the play, she is an Art History professor at the same university where Mark teaches. She’s an organizer, a do-er, a shaker, and she can drink you under the table.

Mark: (Man, early 40s/late 30s, to play age 40 and 38) The chairperson of a small university art department. Caustic, blunt, scathing, icy, but all in an extremely sexy way. Mark wears his militant sexuality on his sleeve, and he prides himself on being a radical sex-positive activist. We don’t know this for a fact, but he’s probably into leather. At the end of the play, Mark is in a long term relationship with Peter. Actor will be seen shirtless in a sheet, with some possible nudity.

Collin: (Man, early 30s, to play age 31) A lawyer. Best friends with British Mark. Collin has recently lost 125 pounds and is celebrating his new-found slender self. He is the glue connecting each member of his little urban tribe.

Evan Wilder: (Man, to play age 30 through 20) *ALREADY CAST*
Michael: (Man, early/mid 30s, to play age 32 and 26) *ALREADY CAST*

PLEASE NOTE:

OUT/PLAY is committed to diversity across race, ethnicity, color, religion, sex, sexual orientation, gender identity, national origin, veteran or disability status.
Directors will be coordinating rehearsals according to actor availability, though availability on weekends is a plus.
Actors must be off-book for all shows.
Director and actors are responsible for promoting the show on social media and through mailing lists. As a non-profit organization, OUT/PLAY needs everyone's participation for success.
All company members will receive a $5 discount code for tickets.

OUT/PLAY's 2025-2026 SEASON

OCTOBER 2025: Caffe Cino One-Acts
DECEMBER 2025: Uncommon Women, by Wendy Wasserstein
FEBRUARY 2026: Love In a Plague: Scenes from AIDS Plays
APRIL 2026: The Homosexuals, by Philip Dawkins
JUNE 2026: Summer Shorts New Play Festival

OUT/PLAY'S MISSION STATEMENT: Empower Queer Theatre Artists to bring new life to Queer plays for contemporary audiences. This season is dedicated to Queers Thru The Years, highlighting playwrights and stories throughout Queer History from 1950s to today.

DURATION

Feb 22, 2026 - Apr 12, 2026

SALARY

$100.00 – $100.00 per gig

UNION

AEA Showcase Code

APPLY ONLINE

https://docs.google.com/forms/d/e/1FAIpQLSdRLuXNXnhHwXq6vdJJM6tt2tcE_bMXyIwyykDZvKiPEF0DwA/viewform

title: DANCE COMPETITION ADJUDICATOR
description:
The PAC Collective
Wilmington, IL
US

CONTACT NAME

Stephanie Starkey
JOB DETAILS
DESCRIPTION

Job Title: Dance Adjudicator

Company: The PAC Collective

Location: Various Locations (Travel Required)
Employment Type: Seasonal / Contract

About Us:
The PAC Collective hosts children’s dance competitions across the country under 4 brands: Precision Arts, LUXXE, Moxie, and KUDO. Our mission is to create unforgettable experiences for dancers, studios, and families. We set the bar high and expect our team to do the same.

Job Overview:
We are seeking knowledgeable, experienced, and passionate individuals with professional dance training and expertise to join our team as adjudicators. Ideal candidates are professionals with experience across all dance styles who are committed to excellence, integrity, and collaboration.

What We’re Looking For:




Versatile background in all major dance styles, including but not limited to jazz, tap, ballet, lyrical, contemporary, and hip-hop.






Strong communication skills and the ability to deliver constructive, encouraging, and articulate feedback to all ages and skill levels.






Positive, adaptable, and ready to collaborate with fellow judges and event staff.






Reliable, punctual, and able to maintain focus during long event days.






Prior judging or teaching experience at a competitive level is strongly desired.




Responsibilities:




Evaluate and score dance performances using The PAC Collective’s criteria and scoring systems






Record verbal feedback for each routine, offering both praise and constructive critiques






Maintain consistency, fairness, and integrity in all scoring decisions






Represent The PAC Collective brand with energy and professionalism throughout the event






Collaborate with fellow judges and staff to ensure a smooth and inspiring competition experience




Requirements:




Availability for weekend travel






Background in dance (teaching, performing, or judging)






Ability to assess dancers across all ages and skill levels






Comfortable working in a fast-paced, live event environment

title: SEEKING PERFORMERS FOR VARIOUS IMMERSIVE ROLES
description:
New York Renaissance Faire
Tuxedo, NY
US
JOB DETAILS
DESCRIPTION

To audition for the New York Renaissance Faire you will need to submit a recording to the New York Renaissance Faire 2026 Audition Form. Submissions will be closed on Monday March 16th, 2026 at 12:00 PM. Callback Invitations will be sent by Wednesday March 25th. Callbacks are scheduled for Saturday March 28th and Sunday March 29th. You will not be considered for the fight based roles if you are not invited or are unable to attend the fight call on Saturday March 28th in New York City in person.




PLEASE HAVE PREPARED FOR YOUR AUDITION SUBMISSION
- Resume
- Headshot
- Two contrasting monologues (approximately 45 seconds each)
-16 bars of your favorite song to sing acapella.
- * If you play an instrument at performance level please prepare a 30-second demonstration.*




FIGHT BASED ROLE AUDITIONS MUST ADDITIONALLY PREPARE:
- Fight Audition Tape consisting the of required material presented in the Stage Combat Audition Choreography 2026




FAE CAST AUDITIONS MUST ADDITIONALLY PREPARE:
- 60 second recording of movement. Pick an animal (DO NOT say which one) and using your full body and multiple levels, tell us a physical story wherein you discover something new in your space. Combine animal like gestures with mystical elements of movement to showcase your fae’s personality and perspective.


To submit your audition, visit our website at renfair.com/ny/join-us/. Any questions can be sent to the nyrfentertainment@gmail.com.



NYRF CAST & ROLES INFORMATION




Daily Rate Range for Performance Days: $64 - $120 (rehearsals are unpaid)




*All roles receive a Day Rate for the 8 weekends of performances between August 15th through October 4th (17 days including Labor Day Monday). Rehearsals are unpaid and opportunity for tent camping is provided. Meals are not provided. Rehearsals are only Saturdays and Sundays from June 13th to August 9th.*




We are casting various roles for several casts including:




Chess Masters: The caretakers of the infamous Chess Board who assist in several shows and host interactive experiences and games for all guests visiting the shire. Roles focus on guest immersion and children centric entertainment while assisting with the overall production.




Fae (Movement Cast): These fantastikal, magical, and somewhat mischievous creatures combine elements of mime, ASL, and movement to bring whimsy, wonder, and a bit of mayhem to the shire for adults and children alike. Roles are focused on movement, and child-friendly entertainment and storytelling.




*Additional audition material required, see above*




Golden Boarstags: The Golden Boarstags, a renown mercenary company, is a cast based around hosting and monitoring the Pub Crawl, a stand alone experience at the New York Renaissance Faire. Additionally, the Golden Boarstags creates and performs a comedic variety show at the end of the day. Throughout the day there is much opportunity to flex your acting chops as we employ ample improv comedy, musical talent and general (but controlled) mischief. This cast does require the ability to walk for long periods, a willingness to engage with guests who are consuming alcohol, and the enthusiasm to create and workshop entertainment with fellow castmates.




*Servsafe certification will be required and training provided for employment.*




Guild of St. George (Includes Fight Roles): Within the greater Performance Company, The Guild of Saint George ensemble provides a theatrical portrayal of the working court of Queen Elizabeth I on royal progress. GoSG achieves the primary goal of inclusion and elevation by welcoming guests into a little slice of Elizabethan courtly life, greeting patrons as fellow esteemed nobility, with pageantry and personability. The Guild of St. George focuses on historical fantasy, ensemble work, stylized movement for the purpose of storytelling, or even sitting one-on-one with guests in a moment of connection across time.




*Including one heightened language monologue would be encouraged for those interested in auditioning for the Guide of St. George cast.*




The Queen’s Blades (Guild of St. George): The Queen’s Blades is a sparring tournament that takes place in the Guild of Saint George for Her Majesty’s entertainment. Six sword fighters, armed with a variety of weapons, will duel in pairs to the disarm or yield, showcasing their skills and competing for the Queen’s favor. All the while, the rest of the Court and the audience propose wagers and cheer for their champions! This show is for those interested in historical martial arts, witty banter and (mostly) friendly competition, and exploring stage combat in a smaller, more intimate setting within the larger scheme of our performance day.




*A Stage Combat Video Submission and attendance at the Fight Call on Saturday March 28th is required to participate. Armed Stage Combat Training is preferred*




The Heralds: The Heralds are a group of nautically-themed performers who bring joy and music to our guests while providing immersive crowd management. There are opportunities to perform at several events during the day, including "Hark the Heralds!" (a singing stage show full of sea shanties), a Pirate Maypole, and hosts various themed balls throughout the season. The Heralds are looking for talented improv performers, actor-singer-musicians, and folks interested in in-character patron management and communication. An adequate dancing ability and a passion for teaching simple steps is encouraged!




Musica Diegetica: Calling all musicians to Musica Diagetica, the heartbeat of the faire. This cast provides the musical soundtrack for the biggest events, including the jousts, chess matches, court dances and maypoles. There are additional opportunities to shine in independent band sets and intimate character interactions. We are looking for intermediate to advanced players with an ability to read music or learn by ear quickly and accurately. All instruments are welcome but we are particularly looking for trumpet, trombone, percussion, violin, viola, and various woodwinds (Electronic instruments need not apply).




Revelers: These rowdy rambunctious rockstars sing songs, dance maypoles, and interact with the audience, creating the thrumming life of shire. Roles focus on improvisation and immersive theater directly with audience members.




Robin Hood Scenario (Fight Cast): The Robin Hood Scenario cast tells the tale of Robin Hood coming into his own as a leader of a Merry Band of outlaws, who come to blows against the power hungry Sheriff and guards. *SAFD training recommended.




Additional opportunities available post casting:




Shakespeare in the Shire:

Shakespeare in the Shire (SitS) is a daily performance that features a rotating lineup of monologues, scenes, songs, and games all taken from or inspired by the works of William Shakespeare. It is an extracurricular of sorts, requiring one extra hour of time at the end of Saturday rehearsal days, with opportunities for director and peer feedback. On the whole, we encourage exploration, play, and creativity to bring the works of the Bard to life!




Within the ensemble, there will be a dedicated small group of improvisers - The Rude Mechanicals - however, there will also be opportunity for large group games, so everyone has a chance to join the merriment. If you love Shakespeare or any part of his works, we’d love to have you!




Requirements: one of your submitted monologues must be Shakespeare




Pastoral Dance Show:

The Pastoral Show is a renaissance period inspired dance show that takes place on the chess board once per performance day! Historically, a pastoral dance is a choreographed performance that celebrates the beauty and wonder of nature and rural living. This cross cast show marries pastoral’s historical thesis while providing a spectacular moment of entertainment for the esteemed guests who come through our gates.

If you are interested in auditioning for the Pastoral Show, please note interest in dancing and your dance level on the audition form when submitting. You can also ask to speak with the Dance Director at auditions. Please note that the dance call to audition for Pastoral will take place on the first “all company” rehearsal day post casting finalizations and contract acceptance.
DURATION

Jun 13, 2026 - Oct 4, 2026

SALARY

$64.00 – $120.00 per day
HOW TO APPLY
APPLY ONLINE

https://renfair.com/ny/join-us/

description:

New London, NH
US

CONTACT NAME

Meg Mechelke
JOB DETAILS
DESCRIPTION

JOB DATES: 6/18/26–8/15/26

Using the framework of themed weeks, NLBP Summer Camps are a fun and educational opportunity for young people ages 6-11. Camps are designed to be an introduction to various theatrical talents including acting, musical theater, technical theater, playwriting, improvisation, dance, puppetry, and more. A single camp takes place Monday-Friday from 9am–4pm, with a showcase for friends and family at the end of the week. This year, there will be 8 weeks of summer camps. Teaching Artists for NLBP Summer Camps should have at least 1 year of experience in theater education with a passion for working with young artists.

RESPONSIBILITIES AND DUTIES:

-Plan and execute an engaging and educational week-long curriculum according to the camp title and theme (with guidance and resources provided by the Camps Director)

-Lead and participate in camp activities which include, but are not limited to, singing, dancing, warm-ups and introducing techniques through relevant acting and musical theatre exercises

-Communicate frequently with the Camps Director before camp start date to prepare, approve, and finalize curriculum

-Communicate with co-teacher to collaborate and distribute duties

-Communicate with Camp Leadership to ensure that all materials needed for camp will be provided

-Teach/facilitate your camp according to your prepared and approved curriculum, working toward a 15-minute showcase at the end of the week

-Provide a fun environment for all campers while ensuring the safety and welfare of participants at all times

-Identify and respond to campers’ classroom conduct

-Communicate with parents about participant’s experiences and report concerns to Camp Leadership

-Classroom set-up and clean-up

-Manage attendance and emergency contact information for campers

-Assist with walking the campers from the camp location to the Barn or Barn-related events nearby

-Provide basic first aid if needed

REQUIREMENTS / SKILLS:

-1 year of experience in education and/or youth theater or equivalent

-CPR/First Aid certification a plus

-Must pass a state of New Hampshire background check

-Comfort with creating lessons plans and documenting curriculum

-Ability to motivate, facilitate and direct youth ages 6-11 and create a classroom culture of respect and participation

-Desire to learn and grow in teaching practice

-Excellent classroom management skills

-Ability to work in a rigorous, fast-paced environment

-Work in a team environment with ability to work independently

-Excellent organizational and time management skills

-Strong interpersonal and communication skills

-A sense of humor and fun

COMPENSATION:

-$3,000 for the season based on experience (paid in weekly installments)

-Housing and meals provided (please read our food policy above)

-Travel stipend

Please email a resume and letter of interest to Camps Director, Meg Mechelke at camps@nlbarn.org

title: ASSISTANT STAGE MANAGER - THE STARTUP WORKSHOP PRODUCTION
description:
The Startup Musical
New York, NY
US
JOB DETAILS
DESCRIPTION
The Startup is a brand new musical premiering its workshop production at The Flea Theater in NYC in April 2026. We are looking for a dedicated, kind and efficient Assistant Stage Manager to join our amazing team for this upcoming production!

Show Synopsis:
The Startup is a sharp, satirical new musical about the price we pay for digital fame. Set in the cutthroat world of Big Tech, it follows Chip Cooper and his idealistic team as they try to build a more ethical social media platform, just as their company teeters on the edge of collapse.

With biting humor and bold heart, The Startup dives into our tangled relationship with technology, tackling everything from social media use and data privacy to influencer culture and the rise of AI. It’s a timely story about ambition, integrity, and what we're willing to sacrifice in the pursuit of success.

ASM Responsibilities:


• Support the Stage Manager in coordinating and managing all rehearsals, technical rehearsals, and performances for the workshop production of The Startup.

• Assist with daily rehearsal operations, including setup, prop tracking, scene transitions, and maintaining a clean and organized rehearsal space.

• Prepare and update run sheets, prop lists, and cue documentation under the guidance of the Stage Manager and Production Manager.

• Oversee backstage operations during technical rehearsals and performances, including performer entrances, quick changes, and prop handoffs.

• Assist in calling cues or running backstage tracks as assigned, ensuring accuracy and consistency throughout the production run.

• Communicate effectively with the Stage Manager, technical team, and cast, helping to coordinate transitions and resolve issues quickly and calmly.

• Attend all production meetings, technical rehearsals, and performances, remaining flexible to evolving production needs throughout the workshop process.

• Adhere to the developmental nature of the workshop and remain open to adjustments during rehearsals and previews.

• Communicate respectfully and professionally with all members of the company and adhere to Equity Showcase Code standards.

• Assist in maintaining a safe, inclusive, and collaborative working environment, ensuring that backstage operations meet the highest standards of professionalism and safety.

Production Schedule:
Rehearsals: Rehearsals will begin with our first read-through/rehearsal on Saturday Feb 28, and will run until we reach our TECH rehearsals beginning Saturday March 28. Rehearals will be Monday-Thursday evenings and Saturdays during the day, with Sundays and Fridays off until TECH.

TECH: ALL DAY Sat March 28 and Sun March 29

Performances:
Dress rehearsal: Tues March 31
Previews: April 1-4
Opening Night: April 8
Run of show: April 8-19
*two shows on Saturdays, OFF Mondays and Tuesdays during the performance run. There will only be one matinee performance for the Saturday 4/4 preview.

The assistant stage manager is expected to be available for tech, previews, and all performances. We can be flexible with any other conflicts you might have during the rehearsal period.

Because this is a workshop production, we are working with a very limited budget. We can provide a stipend of $200 for your involvement with this project.

This is a wonderful opportunity for an emerging stage manager to get valuable experience working on a new work in development. Please email thestartupmusical@gmail.com with your resume if you are interested. Please put in the subject line: "Assistant Stage Manager Submission- THE STARTUP" We are looking to hire this role ASAP, so the sooner you submit the better.

We look forward to hearing from you!

title: SUMMER ACCOMPANIST
description:
Aloha Foundation
Fairlee, VT
US

CONTACT NAME

Bryan Partridge
JOB DETAILS
DESCRIPTION

Job Description: Pianist Accompanist and Counselor at the Aloha Camps

 

Are you a talented theater Pianist Accompanist with a passion for working with children? Do you have a knack for creating a fun and inclusive musical atmosphere? If so, we have the perfect opportunity for you! Join Camp Lanakila as a Piano Accompanist and Counselor, where you can inspire young campers through the power of music.

Responsibilities:

As Music Director

Serve as Music Director for the first half musical. This includes playing piano for the performances. 

Make sure the piano is kept in good condition. This means making sure the cover is always on, and that the the lid is put down over the keys every night.  Since it is practically outdoors the moisture builds up on the keys and it is very unpleasant to play the next morning. Everyone at camp is welcome to use the piano, and most won’t remember to cover the keys when they are done. 

As Camp Pianist:

Provide lively and engaging piano accompaniment for all camp singing at bi-weekly assembly, campfire sing-alongs, talent show performances, and other camp events. Bring the magic of music to life!

Collaborate with campers and other staff members to create musical arrangements and performances. Encourage campers to explore their musical talents and express themselves through music.

Assist and support campers in rehearsing and practicing their individual musical performances. Foster their confidence and growth as musicians.

Occasionally lead group music sessions, teaching campers basic piano skills or introducing them to new instruments. Ignite their love for music!

As a Counselor:

Act as a positive role model and mentor for campers, fostering a supportive and inclusive camp community. Help create lasting memories for campers!

Engage and participate in camp activities and team-building exercises. Foster a sense of belonging and fun for all campers.

Supervise and ensure the safety of campers during all camp activities, including meal times, overnight stays, and off-site excursions. Their safety is our priority!

Qualifications:

Proficient piano skills and the ability to read sheet music, with a diverse repertoire. Show off your versatility in playing various genres!

Prior experience working with children, such as teaching music lessons or leading youth groups. Patience and a genuine interest in nurturing young minds are key.

Strong communication and interpersonal skills, with the ability to connect with campers of different ages and backgrounds. Build trust and rapport easily!

An energetic and enthusiastic attitude, with the ability to create a positive and inclusive camp environment. Infuse campers with your infectious energy!

Perks:

Making a meaningful impact on the lives of campers, fostering their love for music and helping them develop lifelong skills and confidence.

Enjoying the beauty of the outdoors as Aloha Hive Summer Camp is located amidst stunning natural surroundings. Refresh your creativity with nature!

Collaborating with a passionate and supportive staff team, sharing ideas and experiences to create an unforgettable summer for campers and staff alike.

Participating in all camp activities and enjoying the vibrant camp atmosphere. Embrace your inner child and have fun!

Competitive compensation package, including room and board during the camp season. Focus on what you do best while we take care of the logistics.

Ready to embark on a summer of music, fun, and personal growth? Join Camp Lanakila as an accompanist/Pianist and Counselor, and help create camp memories that will last a lifetime!

March 5-6, 2026 from 6:30pm - 9:00pm
Course Level: Professional / Age Requirement: 18+



The class will comprise floor technique, followed by choreography, culminating in character into choreography. You'll come away with tools and techniques to bring a character to life through dance. This class is suitable for all actors, dancers and performers with baseline choreo pick-up ability. Gregory Haney is an accomplished actor, choreographer and movement director with extensive background on Broadway, the West End, and in film, TV and music videos. This course is geared for professional dancers, actors and performers. Whilst participants do not need to specialise in dance, this class does require baseline choreography retention. LAMDA NY Short Courses are presented in partnership with American Friends of LAMDA (AFLAMDA).




BRITISH ACCENTS with LAMDA NY Voice Instructor, Atticus Orsborn
April 25-26, 2026 from 10:00am - 5:30pm
Course Level: Professional / Age Requirement: 21+

This in-depth weekend course is an invaluable opportunity to spend some deep and dedicated time working on your British accent(s). Designed for professional working actors, you’ll be guided through the technical aspects of creating a British accent, before moving on to discovering how to sit in and embody the accent as your own. You’ll be encouraged to find truth, connection and ease over perfection and impersonation, and you’ll finish up the weekend with a reliable British accent(s) you can be confident in.


LAMDA is a truly global drama school, having been ranked 6th by the Hollywood Reporter in its list of the best drama schools in the world. Since its inception in 1861, LAMDA has offered exceptional vocational training to actors, stage managers, technicians, directors and designers, regardless of their background or economic circumstances. With many of our alumni being from the USA and going on to consistently work across Broadway, Off-Broadway, and film and television, New York City was a natural fit for the home of our first international studio.

DURATION

Mar 5, 2026 - Apr 26, 2026

UNION

NON-UNION
HOW TO APPLY
APPLY ONLINE

https://www.lamda.ac.uk/all-courses/short-courses/new-york

title: COSTUMED TOUR GUIDE/ SUPPORT STAFF
description:
Alaska 360 LLC
Skagway, AK
US

CONTACT NAME

Angela McCain
JOB DETAILS
DESCRIPTION

***$16/hr regular wage, $1/regular wage hour worked end-of-season bonus when contract completed. Character Tour Guide / Support Staff are eligible for tips. Guides MUST be able to arrive in Skagway by April 23rd - Training begins April 25th, 2026; Contract End Date is Sept 30th, 2026. Subsidized housing is $300/month, double occupancy, deducted from the paycheck. Pets are not allowed in company housing.***

Position Brief

Alaska 360 is seeking energetic, engaging, and adventurous individuals to join our team of 1890s Costumed Tour Guides and Support Staff for the summer season in Skagway, Alaska. Alaska 360’s Costumed Tour Guides dress in period costumes and take on the personas of prospectors and other members of the 1898 Gold Rush community. As a Costumed Tour guide, you will bring the spirit of the 1890s to life! You’ll guide groups of 12-50 guests on an interactive gold rush experience filled with laughter, storytelling, and local history. This is a hands-on, high-energy role where creativity can shine.

General Responsibilities

Alaska 360 takes great care to train and maintain a professional and knowledgeable cast of characters to perform daily tasks and execute the company’s tour offerings for all guests who visit Alaska 360’s Dredge Town. When you are not leading tours, Costumed Tour Guides/Support Staff will assist fellow guides, support the Back of House (BOH) operations, perform tasks that help upkeep the operations of Alaska 360’s retail center and restaurant areas, and complete tasks to maintain the tour grounds. This position reports to multiple supervisors and managers throughout the day and is expected to carry out the company’s mission and represent the values of the company to the guests and to his/her colleagues. Costumed Tour Guides/Support Staff assume a persona from the Klondike Gold Rush era and work in period costumes.

Key Responsibilities and Accountabilities

Welcome and retrieve guests from the assigned tour from the assigned cruise ship

Works as a Dock Representative for their assigned tour under the supervision of Alaska 360's Operations Team with duties including interaction with guests, transportation companies and cruise ship employees

Acts as a Costumed Tour Guide for their assigned tour, which may include components such as the White Pass train, the Gold Rush Training Camp, the Sixty Mile Dredge, the Campfire, and Gold Panning

Provides support for Back of House (BOH) operations (gold panning, assaying of gold, and/or resetting of the BOH tour elements)

Works in the retail area (mainly assaying gold) as an essential component of the tours

Helps with maintenance and cleaning tasks throughout the day

May assist in opening and closing tasks in the Retail Center and/Restaurant areas on a rotating basis. Tasks may include, but are not limited to, maintaining restrooms and general areas, providing inventory support, assembling snack bags, and other tour-focused supplies, etc

Works daily with multiple supervisors, managers, and partners with other cast members

Ensures a clean, clutter-free work environment

Educational Background

High School Diploma or equivalent (GED)

Degree or training in drama, theatre and/or education helpful

Experience in sales, retail or hospitality a plus

A high degree of knowledge about gold and Alaska through coursework and study is also a plus!

Professional Experience

Experience in hospitality, education, theme parks or tourism- helpful

Experience in sales or retail- a plus

Experience in theatre, education, musical talent, juggling, storytelling, comedy, or other performing or public speaking- desired

Love of history and a desire to inspire others to appreciate it- a necessity

Required Skills & Abilities

Good interpersonal skills for daily interactions with individual guests and groups

Eager to learn and have a growth mindset

Strong presentation/acting skills. Comfortable speaking to groups between 12 and 50 guests

Versatility - fulfill multiple rotating positions and transition quickly between the site segments

Reliable, adaptable, and a great team player

Commitment to making the guests’ experience a top priority

Continued participation and interest in educational material relevant to Alaska, the Klondike Gold Rush, gold, and Skagway

Ability to work as part of a team, including up to 40 employees

Outgoing, friendly, and confident personality

Ability to lift 40lbs throughout the workday

Ability to stand and walk for an 8-hour workday

Ability to work a full season (late April through early October)

Why You’ll Love It

Become part of a company that values collaboration, development, and excellence and join a fun, creative, and supportive team

Work in a challenging but very rewarding job in a fast-paced, high-volume environment with plenty of opportunities for growth

Spend your summer in one of Alaska’s most breathtaking historic towns

Perform outdoors and meet travelers from around the world

Have access to low-cost quality company housing

Gain public speaking, performance, and customer service experience

Build memories—and friendships—that last a lifetime!

Join us this season for a rewarding experience in one of the most remarkable regions of the world.

DURATION

Apr 23, 2026 - Sep 30, 2026

SALARY

$17.00 – $17.00 per hour
